Re: Painting School and Residence Big Horn Reserve.

In reply to your letter No 710-5 (E2), d/ August 8th, we are enclosing herewith written tender by Mr. B.A. Johnson, of Rocky Mountain House, Alta., for the painting of the two buildings at the Big Horn Reserve, which is $500.00.

He has also included a price on the cost of varnishing the floors, which reads $65.00.

The Branch to provide all materials, which are taken care of as to the buildings, except for floors, which were overlooked when the requisitions were sent forward.

The material required for the floors will be varnish and the amount required will be for two coats, 5 Gallons of Spar Varnish at a cost of approximately $32.50, being $6.50 per gallon. May we suggest under the circumstances that this be purchased locally.

In regard to Mr. Johnson's tender, may we say that the sub-contract for the Sarcee Day School only was $1400.00, and we consider Mr. Johnson's bid a very fair one, and would so recommend. We feel that he will do a good job on both buildings.

May we say that both buildings are progressing, with some delay over labour and rains, but we rushing the job for opening of school around the first week in September. Road and bridge conditions have not helped us in the supply of materials, but this is now in hand. The buildings may say look very good to the writer, and certainly are of solid construction.

John. Pugh, Supt.,
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.
Attention: Col. B.F. Neary.
Re: Out-Buildings, Big Horn Day School.

With reference to the marginally noted subject matter, may we refer you to Major C.A.F. Clark's report of June 15th, 1948, indicating to you the number, sizes, construction etc. of the buildings at the Big Horn Indian Reserve, Nordegg, Alta.

In this connection as we are now nearing completion of the two main buildings, namely the school & residence, the out-buildings will require some attention. We note that Major Clark suggested the usual toilet facilities, of which there must be three, residence, boys & girls, and a log building 30' x 20' for sheltering horses or pupils etc.

The item suggested by Major Clark as to cost was placed at $500.00. We have discussed this matter with Mr. Johnson in charge of construction, and have suggested to him, that the toilets be constructed from scaffolding material for studs etc., and if shiplap available at the end of the main building work, that this be used for sheathing on studs, and to finish the three, it is suggested that we cover the outsides with Cedar imitation log siding, and roof with green asbestos shingles in line with the school roofs.

We selected places in rear of the buildings, in a slight depression in the terrain, and all will be placed over holes, with the boys and girls toilets screened by trellis from each other and spaced some distance apart.

In the case of the building, 30' x 20', we have the logs on hand, and it is recommended that this building be on a 4" concrete floor, with 8" x 8" to carry the log walls, and a lean too roof, of 2 x 6 rafters, and roll tar paper roofing in green used to cover on common boards for sheathing, with one door made up from shiplap.

Some part of this building should be used for the storing of Coal, and one end for the storing of supplies for the reserve, and to do so, it is suggested that a partition of shiplap should be installed.

Material for the above proposals was not included in Purchase order No. 44774, and while we have not prepared any costs for the above, we are visiting the site next Monday, and will review the material on hand, and consult with Mr. Johnson as to construction costs, and advise by Air Mail. It is however estimated that the cost of material will approximate $450.00. Labour costs will be ascertained and advised as above. The cost of materials will be divided by the use of scaffolding material, and form material, but a great deal of this was used in putting in the insulation for the subfloor in the school, and our figure may be high. We have sufficient cement on hand, not having put in the full sized basement due to rock formation found at excavating the basement.

Over.
On our last visit to this job, we endeavoured to ascertain completion costs for labour on the two buildings, and found that work sheets up to date at that time, left us with approximately $450.00 in labour account, with all windows to be framed in, floors to be laid, lining in both buildings, and the chinking of outside walls to be carried out, with cement smoothing finish to basement and foundation walls, and rough estimate to complete the above would be around $1000.00 to $1200.00; further check on this will be made Monday next, and request will then be made for further accounts be Cheque from the "Rocky Mountain House" agency.

We have a very solid job on this school and residence, and attractive looking. The writer has taken some coloured moving pictures of the work as it went along and when completed will forward to you for viewing. They are in 8 M size.

May we have your advice and suggestions in regard to the outbuildings, please, as we would like to complete all work while we have a crew on hand.

John E. Pugh, Upt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

Re: Big Horn Indian Day School, Nordegg, Alta.
Wages, School & Residence Buildings.

With further reference to our letter of the 27th instant, even file, it is advised that the writer has just returned from the above school work at Nordegg, and as reporter in the above referenced letter, we find that we shall require a further accountable cheque in the amount of $1500.00 to complete the above buildings.

We checked with Mr Johnson the Foreman, and he advises that it will be about September 20th before completion of the above two buildings, and he will require about four days for the erection of toilets. The estimate, based on the wage rates being paid, will require a further amount as stated above, which will not include the proposed erection of the shed as covered in our letter of 27th instant. For this work it is estimated that a sum of $350.00 for labour and approximately $250.00 for material, requisitions to cover this material attached, should the Branch authorize this shed being built.

We may say that we are a little disappointed at the progress being made in the finishing work as to labour, and we have asked Mr Johnson to speed his work up, consistent with workmanship, and his date line was given as above, i.e.: Sept 20th next, for the school and residence.

May we ask that the Accountable Cheque as noted in the first paragraph be forwarded as soon as possible, please. We would also appreciate the Branch's decision in regard to the shed, which we feel will be essential at this point.

John E. Pugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

It is desired to acknowledge the receipt of Branch File 55-145 (W.I.), dated September 1st last, with reference to the account of Mr Charles Bruce of Rocky Mountain House, Alberta, dealing with the non-payment of accounts for building materials supplied last April.

In reply it is advised that Voucher No 322, in the amount of $1230.07, in favour of Mr Bruce was mailed from this office on the 9th day of June last, the account of Mr Bruce being dated June 4th last. This account represented purchases under Purchase Order No 41088, File 91638-4-3, dated April 1st last.

When checking into this matter, the writer who prepared and forwarded the above Voucher, found several errors in extensions at the time and changed the total of Mr Bruce's account from $1229.67 to $1230.07, and on receipt of your above referenced letter, we re-checked this account and the purchase order above, and again found discrepancies, and as a result we have written to Mr Bruce showing these alterations that will of necessity have to be made, unless the Branch pay the account after a re-check. We have made copies of Mr Bruce's original account, and have made a copy of the Voucher No 322, but we are holding for our files, the last copy of the Bruce written account as rendered to this office on June 4th last.

We are enclosing a copy of the changes that we found in the above account, which we have mailed to Mr Bruce for his checking purposes. It is also pointed out that attached to the original voucher sent forward, a receipt for $154.30 was attached to cover the hauling charges which were to be prepaid by Mr Bruce.

We are concerned over the loss of the Voucher, but we are satisfied that same left this office as above. The errors that will be found are contained in both Mr Bruce's account and also in the Purchase Order No 41088, and are:

(over.)
are:

Extension of 36 pcs of $2 \times 4 \times 16$ @ $52.00 .. $22.46.
not $22.00 as in P/O No 41088. (432 B Feet)
Extension of 1 pc of $8 \times 8 \times 8'$ @ $52.00 .. $2.24.
not $2.34. (43 B Feet)
Extension of 25 pcs of $2 \times 4 \times 16'$ @ $52.00 .. $13.88
not $14.04. (267 B Feet.)

The total of Voucher No 322, should read $1231.37,
as against $1230.07.

When the voucher and purchase order in question have
been checked and the figures corrected, may we suggest that
Mr Bruce's account be paid at the corrected figures and Mr
Bruce advised accordingly.

We regret that we did not carry out a closed check when
we rendered this voucher, having failed to check the figures
on the Purchase order which we took as correct.

Big Horn Indian Day School. Ref Your File 701-1 (E), 4/10/49.

We have for acknowledgement your above referenced letter, and in reply, it is advised that the writer has just returned from a visit to the above school, and found that all inside work had been completed as to Carpenters work, painting had commenced on the residence, and a start was to be made on the school on Sunday.

There remains two sets of stair entrances to be made for the residence, which will be completed when the shed which they have commenced has been completed, using up odd material to make these stairs.

The work performed on these buildings has been good, and the finish work fairly good when one considers that log buildings are not as easy to work as frame. Favourable comments have been made by local and other people on the very presentable buildings erected at this point.

The latter end of the finishing work has been somewhat slow and the date of September given by Mr Johnson proved too short, the actual finishing date of the two school buildings being Oct 8th. We will provide the photographs as soon as possible as requested.

In regard to school supplies, we may say that Mr Bulmer has taken up residence at the Big Horn Reserve, and is making himself useful while not teaching school as was hoped on the 3rd, but we did intend opening up on the 17th, this to give time for the painting and floor varnishing to set. No school supplies have been received, and it is now suggested that sufficient supplies for approximately 15 pupils be forwarded, all of which would be for lower grades 1-2-3, and as the writer is now making and has been making almost weekly trips, we will check with Mr Bulmer and make out a requisition for supplies. We say this as we note that you use the word additional school supplies, and we wonder if any supplies have been sent forward, as such have not come to hand.
to hand:

We made enquiry at the Railway Station at Nordegg, Canadian National Railway, before leaving on Friday evening. We did not make out any requisition, being under the impression that certain supplies would be sent forward as in the case of the Eden Valley Indian Day School. Would you kindly advise us by wire if supplies have been sent forward at all? We regret the oversight if we should have provided you with requisitions for school supplies.

In checking over the supplies furnished by the T Eaton Co., of Winnipeg with Mr Bulmer, we noted some damage to certain articles, these included a crack in top plate of the kitchen range, one glass broken in the Dining room china cupboard, a slight tear in the studio lounge, and a slight tear in one mattress. We feel that these happened when hauling form Nordegg to the Big Horn, the roads being very rough and rocky, and being crated inspection was not made at railway point. The damage to the articles is not great, and repairs can be made except in the case of the stove (kitchen), and this is not serious enough to warrant pulling the stove down to effect the repair. Two or three shortages have been noted and these will be dealt with direct with the T Eaton Co., at Winnipeg.

Mr Bulmer requested us to furnish blinds for the residence, and curtain rods, and a requisition is being prepared which will be subject to authorization.

Storm Doors were not included in the requisition for materials for the residence and it is recommended that these be provided, of a Combination type, storm and screen, and a requisition will be sent forward to cover this item for your consideration.

At this time of writing we have not received any further accountable cheque for school labour, and we would ask that this be provided in the amount of $1500.00 for the school & residence, and an amount of $350.00 as authorized for the shed building, and should these amounts not cover the complete job, vouchers will be submitted to cover the concluding work if required.

John W. Pugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

Re: Big Horn Indian Day School
Your file 710-5 (E)

In his letter of August 31st, Superintendent Pugh asked for a further accountable cheque in the amount of $1500.00 to complete the Big Horn Day School and Teacher's residence. He also requested an advance of $350.00 for labour, if authorized to erect a shed.

On September 19th Mr. Pugh advised that the accountable advance of $1500.00 had not been received and we sent an Army Message to you. On September 30th we wrote you from this office because the advance had still not been received by Mr. Pugh. You wired on October 5th asking if the amount requested was a further $1500.00 because you had apparently forwarded an accountable advance in this amount about September 21st. We replied by Army Message that the accountable advance referred to was still the same one originally requested in Mr. Pugh's letter of August 31st.

In other words, it appears that the accountable advance which you state was sent around September 21st has not been received either at Rocky Mountain House or at the Morley office. Mr. Pugh is presently at Rocky Mountain House and we were in touch with him by phone today. He urgently requires the $1500.00 advance originally requested to complete the school and teacherage, and a further $350.00 advance to complete the shed.

If the $1500.00 was actually sent on September 21st, I have no idea where it is or where it could be unless it was lost in the mail.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

Re:- Cleaning up grounds at Big Horn Indian Day School & Teacherage.

It is desired to submit herewith, Voucher No 714, amounting to $50.00 in favour of Isaiah Crawler, of the Big Horn Indian Reserve, whom the under-signed employed to clean up the grounds of the above school, after the completion of the construction of the buildings at the above point.

While we had no authority to carry out this work, the writer was anxious to haul away broken trees, rocks, and generally clean up the grounds before snow fell, and while the writer was unable to see the clean up before snow fell on my last visit, the teacher, Mr Bulmer assured us that they had made a very good job of raking up and clearing away all rubble etc from the site.

Crawler used other Indians to assist him, but I have issued the voucher in his favour, as we gave him the task of cleaning up etc.

The above work was considered essential for the general appearance of the premises, and I trust the branch will concur in my actions.

We may add that we have prepared the majority of the accounts etc to wind up the above work, but had to return the invoices of the Atlas Lumber Co Ltd, for corrections etc, and we are awaiting these before filing the complete returns for the above buildings.

It is desire to submit hereinafter vouchers covering the construction of the Big Stone Lake School - Teacherage - Shed and Toilets, the above consist of:

Voucher No 667. Freighting supplies to Site.
Voucher No 668. Supply of stove pipes for School.
Voucher No 669. Use of power tools - Cement mixer - Truck by foreman Mr B. Johnson.
Voucher No 670. Dimension material for lumber.
Voucher No 671. Painting by Mr B. Johnson.
Voucher No 672. Varnishing floors by Mr B. Johnson.
Voucher No 673. Credit voucher covering materials purchased.
Voucher No 674. Balance of wages for labour due Mr B. Johnson.
Voucher No 728. Lumber and materials. Teacherage. $10 44777.
Voucher No 729. Lumber and materials. School bldg. $10 44777.
Voucher No 730. Lumber and materials. Extras.

A statement covering the supply of materials as supplied by the Atlas Lumber Co Ltd., on Purchase Orders No 44777 & 44778, and the extras is attached to Voucher 729.

Statement is also attached to Credit Voucher No 673, covering the accountable cheques supplied for this work, and indicating the balance due to Mr B. Johnson in Voucher No 674.

Referring to the material supplied on Vouchers No 728-729, it was found as the work progressed that changes had to be made in the materials being supplied, and we instructed the Atlas Lumber Co Ltd., to show all items that were not on the respective Purchase Orders as extras, hence the three accounts.

In connection with the additional labour, we are fairly well satisfied with the services rendered by Mr Johnson and his crew, but being somewhat remote controlled we had some labour difficulties however we believe that the percentage of labour to materials on the present day building costs has worked out fairly close to that level.

There are possibly two items that the writer acting as "in charge", possibly erred in, (1) That of using ten feet for lining, this does not take paint too well, and we used canvas or linen striping for joints, and we feel that this will not stay put in place and may after a time have to be replaced, either by striping with lattice strips or cementing the joints and repainting. (2) We had difficulty in getting the cement chinking of the logs on the outside to hold, we used metal lath strips, and the cement holds to unite, but where it lapses to the logs, it did not adhered too well, and may have to be gone over later. The lumber co has now agreed to supply us with sash balances at this date, and this we believe is the only item not completed, and when procured, it will be necessary to have Mr Johnson place them in the school cases, and we have left the sash stop partially nailed for this purpose.

Respectfully submitted,

Sir,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant re the reopening of the Louis Bull Day School, and to say that this is the first we hear of this school since December 1893. On September 1897 the matter stood as follows: Hon. Mr. Forget then at Hobema was written to the effect that the work of the school was allowed to continue until certain enlargements to the Red Deer School would allow of the children of that reserve to be removed to Red Deer. He was also informed that there was no provision in the estimates for this school, not to mention the purchase of material to finish a winter school for the same band at Pigeon Lake. This was pursuant to Department's letter No. II8151-7 of the 10th of December 1893.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
It would not cost very much to build a boarding school that would accommodate 35 or 40 children. As we have the sawmill here on the reserve, I think that each man that is head of a family would get out 10 logs apiece for lumber. So there are plenty of logs on the Reserve; this would be a great saving in expense.

Is there any law to compel the children to come to school?

If not, would you pardon a recommendation for every day the children are absent from school but for a good reason, which the teacher should acquaint me or myself with the cause. We charge them cents for each day, and that to the kept off their treaty money, the teacher being present at treaty payment with his school register. I think a small fine would bring them to school more regularly. As it is a shame that a teacher should sit in a school room buried by the gas to teach the children and they will not come. I know I would rather teach 15 or 20 than 5 (or missing 3 or 4). I think it is time for confusion while children have got to go why not the Red.

A. A. Goodhead
Sir,

I have read the contents of the pamphlet regarding tuberculosis. I think that cleanliness is one of the very important things that we need to hang upon our Indian people.

Last summer we adopted the plan of washing the children every Friday afternoon. And we could see a great change in the children, especially did it show itself in the little delicate girl. She is now robust as the others and happy. We wash them in the tub. I wash the boys and my wife the girls. If we had a boarding school so that we had the children all the time, we could keep them clean and healthy. And if we want to save our Indian people, we must save the children. As so many of them die before the age of ten yrs.

Sir,

Re Louis Bull Day School.

Referring to your letter of January 30th, #118151, I beg to say that from all the information I have been able to gain the difficulty is not with the teacher but with the conditions that prevail on that Reserve. The people are very much scattered, and to get anything like a regular or full attendance is impracticable, especially in the winter season. The same difficulty is experienced at Sampson's Reserve, and although the people are being systematically visited by the present teacher, Mr. J.A. Youmans, he finds it exceedingly difficult to keep a Day School in operation.

Perhaps it ought to be said that a further difficulty, and perhaps the chief one, has been caused by the establishment of a Boarding School at Ermineskin's Reserve, while a similar provision for Sampson's and Louis Bull's Reserves has been refused to us. This has caused dissatisfaction among the Indians and a consequent reluctance on their part to send their children to the Day School. Furthermore, they are influenced by rumors current among them, and for which there would seem to be some foundation, that the Department is in favor of Boarding Schools and only Boarding Schools. If the Department is prepared to carry out this policy we are quite prepared to co-operate with it in such cases as White Fish Lake, Battle River, etc.

I will make further enquiry respecting the work of Mr. Goodhand at the Louis Bull School, but I am persuaded that the amount of energy will make the Day School successful under existing conditions.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott.

Regarding the request of the Rev. Jas. H. Bury, of the Church of the Nazarene, for the establishment of a mission and school on the Louis Bull Indian Reserve, to be conducted under the auspices of his church, I beg to say that this Reserve, as far as the spiritual needs of the Indians are concerned, has always been under the domination of the Methodist Church. The census return of 1916 (the last for which figures are available) shows that there were 84 Indians in the Band, 62 of whom were classed as Methodists and 22 as Roman Catholics.

The day school on this Reserve has been closed for several years, but requests have frequently been made by Rev. T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, to have it re-opened. In a recent letter to the Department he states that he has the offer of a teacher, and that the Methodist Church has a building in which it would be suitable to carry on school work, and he requested the sanction of the Department to appoint a teacher and re-open the school. He stated that the delay in building the proposed industrial school at Edmonton makes it imperative that some provision be made to retain the Methodist Indian children until such time as the proposed industrial school is ready for occupation. His request has been referred to Mr. Commissioner Graham.

I might further point out that this Reserve has always been considered as under the auspices of the Methodist Church, and I am of the opinion that they would strongly object to having a school re-opened on the Reserve under the auspices of another religious body and authority granted for a missionary being appointed. This latter point is submitted for your consideration in dealing with the request of Rev. Mr. Bury.

Dear Mr. Graham,

Louis Bull's Day School.

This school is taught by Mr. T. E. Sinclair, and was opened in Jan. 1922. It had been closed for a number of years, so the children have had no previous training. At the present time there are twenty-one on the roll, all in grade one. At the time of my visit there were five boys and four girls present. I examined the children in their work and think they are getting along very well considering the fact that they have only been in school for a little over a year; and also when they entered they could not speak English.

The same thing applies here as at the Samson Day School in regard to attendance - it is very irregular; but I believe Mr. Sinclair is a very conscientious worker and considering the circumstances under which he is laboring, in my opinion, he is doing very well.

Day School Program - Hobbsen Indian Agency.

Reference your 112-6-3 of February 25 -

The Departmental policy with regard to consolidation is that where possible we do not erect one-room schools, but rather, larger schools where a more efficient educational program can be covered.

However, we have experienced considerable difficulty in putting this policy into effect, due to the poor road facilities which exist on most Indian reserves. The main factor in consolidation is that bus transportation can be provided for children from scattered homes, in order that they may be carried to a larger day school.

The one-room day school, of which we have now prepared a standard plan, is such that it can be easily expanded into a two-room school by having an extra class conducted in the basement. This basement has been designed in such a way as to provide ample light. In fact, there is as much light in the basement as there is in the main classroom.

For extra teacher's quarters, the store room and boiler room (for hot water heating) can be easily converted for extra accommodation.

However, it would seem that a thorough educational survey of the Hobbsen Agency should be carried out before any definite decision is reached. If you so wish, we can arrange to have our Educational Survey Officer visit your Inspectorate in May or June and carry out such a survey. I will expect to hear further from you in this regard.

Bernard V. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Hobbema Superintendency:
Proposed Day School for Louis Bull Band:

On May 18 I went to the Louis Bull area with Mr. Superintendent Woodsworth and the Assistant for the area, Mr. T.G. McLeod. It was necessary to drive thirty miles in order to get to a point only six miles from agency headquarters. The visit had been scheduled for an earlier date but all roads were then impassable.

The upper photo shows the general area near the old school where the Indians want the new installation. In the lower photo a man is shown standing behind a stake that marks where the northwest corner of the school should rest. The old school appears in the left rear. The point marked is approximately at "X" in the upper picture. The bottom photo shows the view south to Hobbema, with the band's Catholic mission on the skyline.

The ground shown is high enough to prevent the basement from flooding. Water should not be a problem. A 400 ft well (drilled) is suggested. This work must, I am told, await the completion of hospital well (August 1st).

It appears possible to obtain Indian carpenters, labourers, and a cement worker. Local department officials are already considering possible contractors and sources of materials.

The Indians brought up the matter of religion in the school. With the approval of his fellow-tribesmen one man said: "We want to continue to be Catholics in the morning, Baptists in the afternoon, United Church in the evening, and Sun Dancers when we feel like it." More reasonably, they insisted that they want to model procedures on the pattern of the Alberta public schools. They look for a community-centered school offering some adult education.

The band claims 76 children under 16. They want the 15 who attend Erminekin to attend the day school. I told them that academic progress in a one-room school would probably be slower than in a well-graded school, but they insisted that the day school would have compensating factors. They promised to enforce attendance.

The family farthest away lives 2½ miles from the site. Many parents would like to have their children start school at six, but there will be enough for one teacher to handle with the present age limits. We might look forward to a consolidated school for the upper grades later on in the pattern of the Muncey reserve.

The question of ownership of the site was raised. Rev. A.J. Law, United Church missionary, disclaims any title.

C.A.F. Clark

Dear Mr. Woodsworth:

Re Teacher for the Bull Reserve Day School.

In my last letter sent to you a few days ago referring to the prospect teacher I would like to mention that Arnold Rapske, who has already sent in his application, should be first considered. He is a capable young man and would well fit for such conditions of school activity and social life. I have found out since that he has quite a scholastic standing and I would think that he would seek to qualify for whatever standard he may yet be lacking. If the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa appoint him I would endorse such an appointment.

Would you please let me know as soon as you receive word from Ottawa about Arnold Rapske's application as the teacher of Bull Reserve School. Thank you ever so much.

The people on the Bull Reserve have placed confidence in us in that they asked us to supply them with a teacher. And we surely want to try and place a good teacher there who will do justice to the calling of a teacher. We may humbly say: if we are only given the opportunity by the Grace of God we will satisfy as much as lies within us.

Visiting the Camsell Hospital recently, I also spoke with Narcius Brown. And of his own accord he said that he wants our church to supply the teacher for the Day School on Bull Reserve.

Thanking you for your courtesy and trusting to have a reply soon.

Yours for the betterment of our Indian friends,

Bible Teacher and Missionary

"Fred W. Benke"

Superintendent of Education:

Louis Bull Indian Day School

Religious denomination of teacher:

This question has been discussed with Rev. Fr. Schmidt and the Rev. F.W. Benke. Each wishes his denomination to dominate the operation of this school, and each has the support of some heads of families. If the Baptists turn out to be in the majority, heads of Roman Catholic families who insist on their children attending a school under non-Catholic auspices (as the Baptist majority will certainly require) are inviting sanctions.

I have suggested to the missionaries and to Mr. Supt. Woodsworth that in a few weeks' time each family head living within the school radius be required to make a statutory declaration of his present faith, as oral statements at census-time and petitions with signatures and votes at meetings have proved to be very confusing.

The family head is to be instructed fully that this statement will be used by the Department to determine the type of school to which the Department may send the child. Parents may, of course, on their own responsibility send their children to schools under denominational auspices other than their own. There are Anglican children attending Presbyterian and United Church schools.

The missionaries meanwhile will have a chance to explain to their denominations' adherents the significance of such statutory declarations, and to consider further whether the Louis Bull land will benefit by the application of s. 100 (2). The Baptists are unlikely to be able to nominate a certificate teacher. The Roman Catholics may not be in the majority.
As the band's members were formerly Methodists for the most part, and subsequently United Church; and as they formerly expressed to me a wish to have their day school conducted in the manner of an Alberta public school, if the Baptists prove to be in the majority, and if their denomination cannot supply a certificated teacher, they and their missionary should be requested to accept a certificated teacher of a denomination which is not trying to gain converts on this reserve. Such teacher should be required to restrict religious observances during school-hours, at all times, indeed, while he has charge of the pupils, to such observances as are acceptable to all whose attendance at the school is ordered or agreed upon.

C.A.T. Clark

Dear Mr. Woodsworth:

Herewith I am enclosing the letter from Miss Felicite Strohschein of Wetaskiwin, Alberta expressing her wish to become the teacher in the Montana Reserve Day School. Would you kindly forward this request to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. Thank you. Mr. and Mrs. R. Neuman and myself are well satisfied with the ability of Miss Strohschein. She has been along quite frequently in the different types of mission work among the Indians. And has a special fondness to teach Indian children. The Neuman's will arrange with her about board and room.

May I kindly ask the following about this school on the Montana Reserve: Is this school now fully recognized by the Department of Indian Affairs as a Government Day School?

Will the teacher receive full Government pay when she takes up her duties by the beginning of May, 1950 at the completion of her studies at the University?

In one of our former conversations you mentioned that having the school in our church we would therefore be entitled to receive rent. Would you kindly take this up with the proper officials and let me know their re-action. We are pleased to have your frequent visits to our school and the interest that you show. You have no doubt noticed that church and school in the one building is rather crowded. But we are willing to carry on for a while in such cramped conditions so that our dear Indian friends may receive a better education. But we hope that the time will soon come when the Government will erect a school and rooms for the teacher on the Montana Reserve. I am sure that you are giving these vital matters your thoughtful concern and are urging the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa to take action in the not too distant future. It would be good. Would you kindly give me the information about the Montana Day school as above stated as soon as you find it convenient. Much obliged.

Received with many thanks the permit from the Department of Indian Affairs to erect a Baptist Church on the Bull Reserve. I have forwarded this valuable document to our Mission Headquarters for their further thoughtful and prayerful consideration. And they will take action as soon as feasible. We want to do our best for these people both old and young.

We have also good prospect for a Normal School teacher to take over the new school on the Bull Reserve as soon as it is finished and open for class instruction. Would you please keep me informed as to the developments of the school.

Thanking you for your kind consideration and helpful suggestions.

Yours for the Welfare of the Indians.

"Fred W. Benke"
Hobbema Indian Agency

Re: Louis Bull Indian Day School
Denomination of Teacher

With reference to your 711-1 (E) of October 14th, I beg to inform you that I discussed the matter of denomination of the teacher with Major Clark during his recent visit.

The Louis Bull Indians, especially the heads of families, seem agreed that they desire a teacher of the Baptist faith. At one time, the majority of these Indians were Methodists but seem to have changed their faith.

On September 19th, 1949, at the request of the Chief and Council, a meeting of the Band was held on the Louis Bull Reserve, and a vote was taken to try to get an indication of the type of teacher wanted. The Indians by vote favored a teacher of the Baptist faith and the Chief and Council signed a resolution to this effect. Narcisse Brown, councillor, was absent being hospitalized at the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital in Edmonton and was unable to sign. Previously he has indicated his agreement in the matter.

Due to the effort of the Indian Association of Alberta, the Indians have been led to believe that what shall be an undenominational day school will be established, in which all faiths attend and the various missionaries are allotted time for religious instruction. Regarding the matter of a sworn statement as to religious affiliation indicated by Major C.A.F. Clark in his letter of October 16th to you, could we be advised further about this?

CALGARY, Alberta,
July 16th 1947

There is a persistent demand for day schools on various Reserves in this province.

Hobbema Agency

There is a demand for a day school on the Louis Bull Reserve. A building which was used as a day school many years ago still stands at a point where there should be between fifteen to twenty pupils. We are informed that it could be made usable for less than $500.00 in repairs, and that a teacherage could be built at a point where there is good water, and not over one-half mile from the school.

The foregoing is brought to your attention in order to ascertain what is the policy with regard to day schools in this province. Is the Branch prepared to start day schools this year if suitable accommodation can be found and teachers located to man the schools. Until this is known there is nothing more that I will attempt to do.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Alberta Inspectorate.

Mr. G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

Re: Day School Louis Bull Reserve

I beg to inform you that the well drillers have secured water on the site of the Louis Bull Reserve.

They assure me it is a good well. In this area water is at a depth over 400 ft. This was known by previous drillings in this area. We were very lucky to secure water as some drillings to the north west have been unsuccessful.

Mr. McLeod Assistant and myself inspected the flow of water at this well. After testing over an hour we found an undiminished flow with slow pumping of over 2½ gal. per minute. This supply will be adequate for any demands.

For your information the following data was secured.

1. Water flow at 2½ gal. per minute or 150 gal. per hour.
2. 3" casing used supplied by agency from Ermineskin stock pile 224 ft. from top.
3. Well drilled to depth of 405 ft. Water rises in well to 120 ft. from top.
4. Impossible to pump by hand small 1½ H.P. motor at least required. Well drillers advise slow pumping. If power installed pressure tank should be put in.
5. 1 5/8 x 16 cylinder needed.
6. 180 ft. of 1" pipe.

The well has been capped pending decision of Department in purchasing pipe and pump and pump engine. The well drillers are available to supply or install this equipment.

(sgd.) H. N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

I visited the site on the Bull Reserve picked for the new Day School and I also surveyed the general situation on the Samson and Ermineskin Reserves. On these two reserves there are a number of children not receiving any education and I believe that these children with other pupils, who are now attending residential schools, could be put into a two-roomed school located near the village of Hobbema, provided transportation was available. Re: Louis Bull Indian Day School

With reference to your 711-5 (E) May 16, 1949, I beg to inform you that I have approached Mr. Hagen and Mr. Wilson as prospects for the job as foreman carpenter, building the Louis Bull Day school. Both men are unavailable.

Jim Potts, Treaty Indian of the Samson Reserve, living at Pigeon Lake has been approached, and after careful consideration of the fact that he is an Indian and that there is a general prejudice against employing Indians in responsible positions, I find myself willing to recommend his services. This man is continually employed by whites as a carpenter and paid at highest rates. He has taken on the job many times of building houses, being solely in charge of construction. He is able to read blue prints. According to Mr. T. G. McLeod, Assistant, his workmanship is of a standard, if not above that of most white carpenters.

I suggest that you proceed with ordering the required materials and we should receive an accountable cheque for two thousand dollars to pay labor immediately.

In view of your stated delay in securing cement, I suggest that we use cement belonging to the Department of National Health and Welfare, at present stored in our garage. Due to moisture conditions, the cement seems to be deteriorating. There are approximately 100 or more bags on hand. The Department of National Health and Welfare also have some form shipload on hand here that though used, would be satisfactory. If you could get the Director of that Department to authorize this arrangement, we would account for the material used of which they have an inventory and proceed at once with the foundation of the school. Gravel would have to be purchased locally from Gee or Ponoka, who has a gravel pit. Other material needed would have to be purchased by the Department.

If you think this arrangement satisfactory, especially in the case of the cement, we will make every effort to facilitate and build this school with a minimum of expense.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

Re: Louis Bull Indian Day School wiring for electricity.

With reference to your 711-5 (E) and to the part regarding wiring for electricity. To date we have not been able to secure other than an approximate estimate of the cost of putting in hydro to this school from the Calgary Power Ltd. Their line crosses the reserve a little over a mile from the site of the school. There are two advantages in having electricity run into this school:

(1) Most classrooms operate during the short daylight periods and I have found the usual country school without light to be a pretty dark place, especially around four o'clock in the winter months.

(2) A good teacher will be easier to entice to the position if we have power.

(3) Elimination of fire hazard using lamps.

If you consider it in order I will secure tenders for wiring and this could be done shortly as the construction of the school is now going ahead rapidly. Material seems to be arriving slowly though we are arranging for shortages as they become evident so not to hold up the workmen.

Re: Eavestroughing
Louis Bull Day School

I note that plan 885 does not include eavestroughing. It is not my desire to bring up any East-West controversy, but I would, nevertheless, like to point out that all buildings in Alberta are so equipped. In the coastal regions and the East, although rainfall is heavier during the season, it does not fall in such a short time as on the prairies. It has been found in this area that eavestroughing is necessary to remove the water from the immediate vicinity of the building and to direct it so as to avoid damage to the building and prevent ponds being formed around the structures.

It would be appreciated if eavestroughing was approved for the Louis Bull Day School.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

Re: Peigan Indian Day School

(1) Wiring.

As discussed over the telephone today, you should send a wire to Col. Neary stating that you have a tender of $220.00 to do the wiring only in the new day school and teacherage. For the time being you should not consider extending the wiring to any other buildings, just the school room and the teacher's quarters need be completed. As soon as Col. Neary sends his approval you can ask the electrician to commence. I did not ask you to get a price on fixtures because I think the Department should state the type of fixtures that should be installed.

(2) Plumbing.

Major Clark suggested that a bathroom might be considered, and Col. Neary in his letter of November 16th, file 751-1 (E) stated that he would appreciate any recommendations which might be made to provide such facilities. The teacher being considered for this school is a married man with two small children. I definitely agree that at least a water supply and preferably a bath and toilet should be provided in this school. We have no authority to do so but I cannot see where it would be possible to provide a bathroom in Plan 888. The rooms are too small now to accommodate the teacher and his family. If a bathroom is installed there will have to be an extension to the building.

I suggest you proceed as follows:

(a) Obtain a price on the cost of extending the present Agency-Hospital water supply to the school. This will at least provide a supply of water in the kitchen and obviate the necessity of carrying water all the way from the hospital by pail.

(b) Discuss with the contractor the possibility of erecting an extension to the building to provide a bathroom if such an extension is possible without spoiling the appearance of the building.

The main consideration now is the price on getting the water supply to the teacherage.

If Mr. Osterberg thinks that a bathroom extension is possible, he might be able to give you some rough idea as to what this would cost, including the fixtures, installation and septic tank.

I repeat, we have no authority to do any of this extra work and it must not be undertaken until the Department has indicated approval.

Major Clark and I were at the Peigan Reserve yesterday. The day school is under construction and Mr. Osterberg, the contractor, informs me that with reasonably good climatic conditions it can be completed by Christmas.

The contractor and Mr. McMillan brought up two matters:

(1) Wire for electricity. Unfortunately we should have used the plan adapted for locations near hydro-power. The agency is served by hydro-power (Calgary Power Company) and Mr. McMillan is endeavouring to have the line extended from the hospital over a distance of about 175 Ft. without cost to us. The school should therefore definitely be wired and I have asked Mr. McMillan to obtain a bid from a Pincher Creek firm covering only the rough installation of outlets, etc. and avoiding installation of fixtures for the time being as you may have some instructions with regard to the type of fixtures used in our schools.

(2) Mr. Osterberg mentioned the fact that some of the moldings and casings provided in the bill of materials are no longer stocked in Alberta lumber yards. We have experienced this before in the construction of staff residences. He is mainly concerned with the casing. The type mentioned in the bill of materials must be milled and the mills are so busy that he cannot expect delivery for some time. However, the yard stock both Victory and Miracle casing. I recommend that he be authorized to use Miracle casing as this is every bit as good as the casing provided in the bill of materials. Please advise.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Pigeon Indian Day School.

Included in our Main Estimates is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of the above one-room Indian school and attached teacher's residence, situated near Brooks, in southern Alberta.

Tenders were called by advertisement for the erection of this school and on the official opening date of September 29, 1949, only one tender had been received. This was from Bennett & White Calgary, Limited, and was in the amount of $22,391.00.

As we have had this particular school building erected elsewhere at a cost of between ten and twelve thousand dollars, we felt that this tender was too high entirely. Then on October 15, 1949, another tender was received from R. Osterberg, 2022 Seventh Avenue South, Lethbridge, Alberta. This was in the amount of $12,560.84. Please find attached copies of two letters (a) from Regional Supervisor Gooderham and (b) from Mr. Osterberg, concerning the delay in forwarding his tender to the Department.

Even though Mr. Osterberg's tender was delayed in reaching the Department, I would recommend that a submission to Council be made covering the acceptance of his tender, in view of the fact that it is $10,000 lower than that of Bennett & White Calgary Limited.

Director.

SEALED TENDERS addressed to the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada, and endorsed "Tenders for Pelican Indian Day School," will be received until noon on

SEPTEMBER 29, 1949

for the construction by contract of—

1. One-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence, Pelican Indian Reserve, near Pelican, Alberta.

Contractors shall tender in complete accordance with the relevant drawings and specifications accompanying documents supplied by the Department of Mines and Resources. Contractors may tender on one or more of these contracts.

The above specifications and other documents will be exhibited at the following offices from September 1 until September 29, inclusive:—

1. Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alta.
2. Superintendent, Indian Agency, Brockton, Alta.

General instructions to tenders, drawings and specifications are obtainable at the above offices upon deposit of Five Dollars ($5.00) in cash or a certified cheque payable to the Receiver General of Canada. This deposit will be refunded when returned with the drawings and specifications in good condition to either

1. Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alta.
2. Superintendent, Indian Agency, Brockton, Alta.

within one month from the date on which tenders close.

To ensure consideration, tenders must be submitted on the tender forms provided and must be accompanied by a certified cheque on a chartered bank in Canada, payable to the order of The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources, equal to ten per cent (10%) of the amount of the tender, or Banker Bonds of the Dominion of Canada or of the Canadian National Railway Company and its constituent companies, unconditional guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Dominion of Canada, or of the aforementioned companies, and a certified cheque if required to make up an odd amount.

The Department reserves the right to reject all tenders and the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

Re: Peigan Indian Day School

As you are aware, we recently advertised for tenders for the erection of the above one-room school and attached teacher's residence at Brocket, Alberta.

These advertisements were for a standard one-room school with attached teacher's residence, in accordance with Plan 388. This school has been costing from $8,750.00 up to $13,000.00, depending on the location.

Only one tender was received for the erection of this school, that of Bennett and White, Ltd., Calgary, Alberta. It was for the amount of $22,291.00. This is so much higher than any other tender which we have received for this type of school, that I cannot recommend its acceptance.

This is not an isolated reserve, in fact a good highway passes within 200 yards of the school site. I would suggest that we advertise again for tenders next spring, and if none are received within a proper price range, that we consider the possibility of erecting this school by day labour with the Department purchasing all the material.

Bernard F. Neary,

Ref: Peigan Indian Day School
Ref: yours to Superintendent McMillan
dated August 3, file 715-5 (E)

I spent the 5th and 6th on the Peigan Reserve and concluded that it would be unwise to advertise for a teacher until the Community Hall is repaired.

You have received tenders for this work from Mr. McMillan and it is hoped that they are acceptable.

I not only inspected the building but met Contractor Neilson who is prepared to do all the carpenter work, also principal of the Highland Motors and saw a Shafco oil fired Heater, similar to that which he is prepared to install in this building.

I was favourably impressed with Mr. Neilson. I learned from him that the insulation contract is submitted by an associate. The Shafco Oil Heater, in my opinion, is ideal for this building and the cost of fuel will be less than coal. Furthermore, no fireman is needed.

As for the wiring and lighting of this building, there appears to be no alternative but to follow the provincial regulations although the building is already wired. Should these contracts be approved, it will then take some time before the work can be completed. I doubt if the school can be ready for pupils before the first of January.

On this assumption, I suggested to the Superintendent and the Principal of the R.C. School that pupils be taken into the residential schools in September without undue consideration of a day school. It is expected that there will be at least 30 pupils who cannot be enrolled at the residential schools but to designate who must wait for the day school will cause confusion. When the day school is opened, a readjustment of residential and day pupils can be readily made. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. McMillan.

G. H. Gooderham,

Attention B F Neary Esqr.

In reply to your letter of the 4th inst, re the establishment of a Day School at the Peigan Indian Agency, and your wire to Mr Gooderham of July 26th re requisitions on the repairing of Peigan Indian Community Hall to make it suitable for a day school, I have been in touch with contractors for the necessary bids, and list of materials since the receipt of your letter of July 4th.

Classroom. Gunner Nielson has been in touch with this work for some time and on Tuesday checked it over with another contractor, and has promised me a list of material and labor bid, as soon as possible, which should be before the last of the month.

Lighting. Pincher Creek Electric has checked this hall up with the idea of fluorescent lights at the East End of the Hall where the classroom will be situated the rest of the Hall will be ordinary lighting. The man checking this work had to get the instructions of the Electrical Insp. for the Province, which has just arrived, and his bid will be turned in immediately.

Heating. The only mode of heating for this Classroom will have to be the Blower type, run by oil, and Mr Stark of Highland Motors, who has one in his Garage, and is the Agent has written away for price and full information which I will pass on as soon as received.

Over.
Desks. I am requisitioning for the desks on the basis of ten small, ten large, and ten medium.

Blackboards. I am requisitioning, for two blackboards, one 10' and one 6' which should be enough.

Janitor supplies. I have noted the authority to purchase the necessary equipment for cleaning the school etc up to $50.00

Teacherage. As I have been advised that the Sacred Heart School authorities, have been unable to procure a Sister for the Day school, I have asked the Contractor to include in his bid the completion of the two rooms in the West end of the Community Hall. It would therefore be necessary to furnish the rooms for the type of Teacher hired.

Classroom Supplies. Your remarks are noted.

Teacher. As the Sisters have received word from their Headquarters their inability to supply a Teacher, owing to a shortage, will the advertisement be placed by the Branch, in the papers, or do you wish me to place the notice in the papers in the south of the Province. If so may I have a rough copy of the ad, I should put in, as I notice the salary schedule for First Class Certificate calls for 1680 to 3120, and the second class from 1560 to 2040.

I sincerely hope to get this work done and have school ready before Sept 1st, however with the inability of getting any other but Local contractors to bid, I feel I am on the spot, as we have two or three projects to complete, and a chance of the same contractor getting the bid, may cause loss of time.

Anthony McMillan
Superintendent.

Will Air Mail requisitions and bids as received.

Peigan Indian Day School

An Order-in-Council has now been passed for the establishment of this school, and it can be referred to as the "Peigan Indian Day School" with code number 715, for requisitions, vouchers, etc.

We will expect to receive from you in the near future, the bill of materials which the Departmental Purchasing Agent can order.

Classroom: We are agreed to leave the classroom as one-room, in order to avoid any extra installation.

Lighting: We are prepared to install fluorescent lights in the main classroom but it is only to be installed in the part of the room where the pupils will be working. It is not felt that more than thirty pupils will be enrolled and, therefore, we do not need to provide lighting for the whole room.

Heating: Please submit a requisition for a blower type of unit which will be sufficient to heat the main classroom.

Desks: Please order sufficient desks in small, medium and large sizes to cover your requirements.

Blackboards:

Please submit a requisition covering blackboards which come in 4½ foot widths. Standard lengths are 6", 8", 10", and 12".
Janitor Supplies: You can make local purchase of $50. of such items as toilet paper, paper towels, soap, brooms, dust bane and smaller items required to get the classroom and teacherage clean.

Teacherage: I understand that the teacher will be living in the Sacred Heart Residential School and will commute daily to the day school. If this is correct, then the only furniture we will require for the teacher's room will be a table, chairs, linoleum rug, curtains and possibly a studio couch. Would you please confirm this so that we can requisition for this furniture.

Classroom Supplies:

We are arranging to forward a standard list of classroom supplies. The teacher may requisition for other items as soon as she reports for duty in September.

Teachers:

Please find attached an application form which you may have the teacher complete and return here when she has been nominated. This will then enable us to state her salary in accordance with our teachers' schedule.

In view of the short supply of desks and blackboards, I would ask you to requisition for these as soon as possible.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

WHEREAS the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources reports that there are forty (40) Indian children of school age on the Peigan Indian Reserve, Peigan Indian Agency, Province of Alberta, for whom educational facilities are required; and

Sir,

Fearing I would not have the time to spare to visit the Joseph's Band of Indians I asked Mr. Agent Verreau to interview them on this subject and to get an assurance from them that they would regularly send their children to the school, if reopened, and in event of them failing, after once given a chance, to carry out their promises that it would be understood at the outset that the school would be closed and the children of school age, and in good health, taken to one of the boarding or industrial schools.

Mr. Verreau has reported about as follows:

There are 33 boys and 19 girls aged from 7 to 14 years members of the Joseph's Band. They reside from 1/2 to 4 miles from the site of the old school, most of them within 1 mile.

Mr. Verreau states that the Indians promised him that they would agree to keep up an average attendance of 18 for 10 months of the year providing they were given a school and a free mid day meal. Mr. Verreau states that it would cost $100.00 for the necessary repairs to the old school building and that it would, too, be necessary to have the children gathered, conveyed, to the school each morning, that a married couple would expect about $75.00 or $65.00 per month and rations to do this work—woman as teacher and man outside work. I observe from his letter that he fears the promise

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
promise he states was given by the parents, i.e., average attendance or 18 for 10 months per annum, would not be of long duration and that it would soon be necessary to place them within one of the residential schools.

My impression is that the Indians, or many of them, would soon forget their promises and that the attendance would soon be nearer 8 than 18, that during the short winter days they would not be in the class room more than an hour or two and that little real progress would be made. If the Department, however, is desirous of testing the zeal of these Indians to secure an education for their children the expenditure of about $1500.00 will prove whether they are in earnest, and if they are not action might be taken then, if thought desirable, to secure a number of the children for residential schools.

St. Albert, Alta. Dec. 1 1904.

Mr. Verreau, Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Verreau,

With reference to our conversation the other night, I beg to say that I do not feel justified to recommend any person for the position of teacher of a day school at Lake St. Ann Reserve. I do not think that there is a person living, man or woman who could make a success of such a school at said place.

And permit me to disclose my frank opinion on this question of day schools for our Indians. Of course I leave out altogether the question of the Reserves in Eastern Canada, the conditions of which I do not know but for our Indians in these western countries I know that they are not prepared as yet for day schools even of an improved system and they will not be prepared for a long time yet until several generations of the parents have been trained in Boarding Schools. Everyone acquainted with the circumstances of our Indian Reserves in the west very well know that Day schools here would be only a sham; the attendance would be illusory and these schools would stand there as a pretext not to send the children to Boarding Schools.

The training in Boarding Schools is certainly more easy, more satisfactory and more thorough and it would be a great pity to do anything that would tend to deprive the Indians of such Training.

This is my honest opinion on the whole subject and I would be pleased if you would send a copy of this letter to the Department.

Believe me Dear Mr. Verreau,

Yours very sincerely

(Signed) Emile J. Legal.
Ottawa, January 12, 1912.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Indians of Joseph's Band (Alexis Reserve) have applied for the re-opening of the day school on their reserve. There are reported to be 42 children of school age; most of whom reside within one mile of the school. An examination of the returns from the St. Joseph's Industrial School and the St. Albert Boarding School does not show any children enrolled from this band. The Department has expressed its willingness to repair the buildings and provide the salary of a teacher.

A copy of Your Lordship's communication in reference to the re-opening of this school has been forwarded through the office of the Inspector. The Department, while fully appreciating Your Lordship's attitude towards day schools in the diocese and the reasons therefor, is of opinion that the re-opening of this day school would be of benefit to these Indians, as they are evidently not in favour of sending their children to the residential schools. If the Indians are sincere in their representations a fairly successful school should be the result.

It is said that accommodation for a teacher is available, and, if Your Lordship will nominate a competent person, the Department will provide a fair salary and call upon its officials to give every assistance possible towards the carrying on of the work. With the co-operation of the

Right Rev. E. J. Legal,
Bishop of St. Albert,
St. Albert, Alta.
Departmental officials and the Missionaries there should be little doubt as to the success of the school.

In view of the circumstances as above set forth I should be glad to further hear from Your Lordship in reference to the matter.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
To the Secretary of the Indian Department,
Ottawa.

St. Albert, Alta., Jan. 28, 1912

Dear Sir,

Replying to your communication of the 12th inst. (File No. 116689/1.) concerning the project of reopening the Day School on Alexis Reserve (Lake Louise), I beg to say that my opinion based on my whole experience of Indian ways in the West, is so strongly adverse to these day schools, that I feel it is my duty bound, not to encourage in any way such a move.

Of course, I have no power for preventing one more trial and one more certain failure.

I do not know of any person whom I could recommend for the position of teacher, and there is no one to whom I could conscientiously recommend to accept the position, knowing as I know, how thankless and disheartening would be the task.

I have the honor to remain, dear Sir,

Your very obediently,

Emile J. Royer
Archbishop of St. Albert.

Sir,

As directed in your letter of the 5th instant I have inquired regarding the possibilities of operating a day school on the St. Joseph's Reserve and the evidence I have gathered leads me to the conclusion that the school, if opened, would not be a success unless it is thought that the children could make satisfactory progress by attending school for only two months, from about May 1st until about September 1st, for I have been assured that this is the only period of the year that the majority of this band are or ever were on their reserve. Then, moreover, would the children of this reserve attend a day school regularly even during the whole time referred to.

Mr. Agent Verreau seems to entertain the view that if he could spare the time during the months alluded to spend 10 days at a time, and on two or more occasions, at that reserve during the period the Indians are at home that he could get the greater number of the children of school age of this reserve into one of the boarding schools if you so desired.

The reason given by Mr. Verreau that he has not spent more time at Joseph's and other reserve is because he has no confidence in his assistants—Mr. Rance.

I am of the opinion that His Lordship has given you a very reasonable prophecy of what would be the outcome if an attempt was made to operate a day school on Joseph's Reserve.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, February 25, 1912.

Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence in connection with the opening of the day school on the Alexis Reserve in your Agency I beg to say that, in view of the reports made to the Department as to the probable success, it is not considered advisable to re-open the school at the present time.

Mr. Inspector Markle states that you are of the opinion that you might be able to recruit a number of the children from this reserve for the boarding schools and I would ask you to use your best endeavors in this direction during the coming summer and report success to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Alexis Indian Day School

Please find hereunder two self-explanatory reports from Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson and Mr. Regional Supervisor Gooderham concerning the fire which destroyed the teacherage at the above Indian school.

It would seem that this building was destroyed by an over-heated stove and that every reasonable precaution had been taken in erecting the teacherage.

You will note that a building is available which could be used as a teacherage until a new one can be erected. I would recommend that Mr. Gooderham's suggestions be followed and that this building be used pending the erection of a new log teacherage.

We have funds available for the purchase of new furniture and for the continued operation of this school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Confirming my telegram of today, I regret to advise that the Alexis Reserve teacherage and furnishings were completely destroyed by fire yesterday, Sunday, December 11/49.

I received a long distance telephone call from the teacher, Mr. Dockery, at 2 P.M. saying that the teacherage had been destroyed by fire. Mr. Bergen, the man who erected the buildings, has been working at the Stony Plain Reserve and I arranged to pick up Mr. Bergen and Mr. Callihoo, Farming Instructor at Stony Plain Reserve, and drove out to Alexis Reserve, to see if we could ascertain the cause of the fire.

Mr. Dockery states that he had been doing some work in the school and on his return about 11 A.M. they smelled smoke and noticed smoke coming from the wall, in the living room, around the opening to the chimney. They doused it with water and the smoke stopped. Unfortunately neither of this old couple is very active and Mr. Dockery went to call some Indians to have help available if it should start up again. Mrs. Dockery states that after her husband left she could hear fire in the ceiling over the living room and by the time Mr. Dockery got back with help the building was a mass of flame. One of the Indians managed to get out the dinette table and four chairs and the arm-chair from the living room, and Mrs. Dockery got out the blankets from the bed. Everything else was a complete loss.

Mr. and Mrs. Dockery are under the impression that the fire was caused through some fault of the chimney but both Mr. Bergen and myself are satisfied that it started from an overheated pipe from the heater in the living room. The chimneys in these buildings are constructed of cement chimney blocks on a cement foundation.
The blocks are well cemented together and the chimney plastered with cement on the outside to eliminate any possibility of cracks. We inspected the entire chimney in the School building and it is standing up perfectly.

The chimney in this building was in the kitchen, against the living room wall, with an opening through the wall for the pipe from the living room heater. This opening was some six inches wider than the pipe and was well insulated with asbestos board both around the opening and on the ceiling above the pipe, and should have been quite safe. There was a wood fire in the heater and the only cause we can figure is that they forgot to close off the drafts and it got going too hard.

As there was no other living quarters for them on the Reserve, I brought Mr. and Mrs. Dockery to Winterburn and for the present they are staying in the teacher's residence for Stony Plain #2 School. Mr. Leskiw is driving out and back from his home in Edmonton and is not using his living quarters as yet, this winter. The School at Alexis Reserve will have to be closed in the meantime. However, if some arrangement for living quarters can be made by the first of January, this will only mean one week extra Christmas Holidays.

The Department own a fire room house in Glenevis village, about three miles from the School. The Health Services are using one room for a dispensary and examination room and we are using two rooms for a ration store house. If a new set of furnishings could be ordered at once, two or three of the rooms in this house could be cleaned up and would make quite comfortable living quarters. This would, of course, necessitate the arranging of transportation to and from the School for Mr. Dockery. Mr. Pope, the Postmaster at Glenevis, operates a small motor livery and I think arrangements could be made with him to take Mr. Dockery out and back from the School for between $30.00 and $40.00 per month as long as the road is not blocked with snow. Should he be unable to get through, similar arrangements could be made to have an Indian drive Mr. Dockery by sleigh. This is the only method I can see of getting the School in operation again by the first of the year. The attendance at the School has been much better than I had anticipated and I am very anxious to keep it going without too long a break, while awaiting replacement of the residence provided, of course, the Department decides to make such replacement, and for which there does not appear to be any alternative.

Should you decide to follow the plan I have suggested, it will not be necessary to purchase new buffet table and chairs or a kitchen range. The range in the burned residence was destroyed but the one purchased for Stony Plain #2 can be used at Alexis as the Stony Plain #2 residence had a range already installed in it and this can remain there for the present at least.

Con't.
Will you please let me have your instructions in the matter as early as possible.

Mr. Dockery is willing to live in the Glenevis house and drive to and from the School.

E. A. Robertson,
Superintendent.

Indian Agencies,

Col. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,

Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re: Alexis Indian Day School, Edmonton Agency.
Your file 42110-9-2

You have been advised by wire that the log teacherage at this school was burned to the ground on the 11th inst. In a phone call today, Mr. Robertson states that he believes that it was caused by an over-heated stove and it is inferred that the teacher and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. Dockery, were in Edmonton at the time.

They have been moved temporarily into the cottage supplied for the teacher of the second school at Winterburn as the present teacher is a bachelor and does not occupy it. This is many miles away from the Alexis School, therefore the Alexis School is closed.

In the village of Glenavis which is situated on the north side of the Alexis Reserve and at the head of a road which we built through the reserve past the day school, Indian Affairs and the Department of Health and Welfare purchased a house which is used as a rationing and clinical centre. It is substantially built and with very little cleaning up will make a very comfortable home. It is a two-story building and rations and medical supplies can be transferred to the part which is not needed for living quarters. It is our recommendation that this house be made the teacherage until such time as a new one can be erected beside the school.

Mr. Robertson believes that the services of a local Glenavis citizen can be secured for about $30.00 a month to take the teacher back and forth to the school which is three miles south of the village. This would be done by car when roads were passable and by sleigh at other times.

As all the furnishings were burned a new supply must be purchased immediately. Stoves will not be needed as there is a heater in the house and the cook stove supplied for the Stony Plain cottage was not set up there since there was already a departmental cooking range in it. The remainder of the standard furnishings, plus blinds, will be required. These must be obtained as quickly as possible as the new teacher for Stony Plain will want to occupy the Stony Plain house on or before the first of January. I suggest you give the Superintendent of the Edmonton Agency authority to purchase the furnishings required for Alexis, in Edmonton. If necessary, he could get prices from the T. Eaton Co. Ltd., the Hudson's Bay and Woodwards and wholesale.
While Mr. Dockery is at Winterburn, it is suggested that he be required to assist Miss Hirondelle. It is known that she is not making as much progress as desired.

Awaiting your early reply.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

P. S. If authority is given to occupy the house, authority to purchase extra coal will be required.

Referring to your letter of September 8, in connection with the above. These buildings are now completed with the exception of putting on the siding on the gable ends of the residence. This will be done within the next few days.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Alexis Indian Day School

Last winter we arranged for the cutting of logs by the Indians of the Alexis Indian Reserve so that this building could be erected during the summer holidays. I would, therefore, recommend to you that approval be given for his hiring as a foreman-carpenter on the erection of the Alexis Indian Day School at the rate of $1.00 per hour.

Sir,

When at Wabunum Reserve recently I was requested by the Chief and Band of Indians resident there to place before your Department their earnest wish for a Boarding School. They claimed that there are people of the same faith with them at Stony Plain, and Pius, Lac La Biche and also at Lake St. Anne who would send their children to the school. They also claim that at this present time they have 17 children at the Red Deer Industrial and also some 30 children of school age on the Reserve for whom they desire education at home. They claim that they have been told that the Red Deer School is to be closed and that schools are to be established at Hobema and Spraddle Lake, and Morley and that...
As the nearest of these would still be one hundred miles from them they do not desire to send their children so far away as also among an alien people. They say that now they have grown to a strong appreciation of the advantages of schools and humbly ask your department to throw funds for them on their own Reserve and adjacent to these other Reserves which are near to them.

James Fairlie

Sir:-

I am enclosing herewith a report on the Samson Day School, which was inspected by Mr. E.L. Fuller on the 20th of November. The school is taught by Miss Mildred Logan, and is under the auspices of the Methodist Church. The Inspector points out that the teacher is meeting with fair success, but she has not the special training actually required for teaching Indian children.

I would draw your attention to the very poor attendance at this school, the number of children enrolled being 79% of those that should attend, and the average attendance for the month of October 79% of those enrolled.

I understood when the question of erecting the School at Edmonton was decided upon, it was with the understanding that all those Protestant children at the Hobbema Agency would be sent to this school and the Day Schools closed. I think this should be done without delay. The Edmonton School has never been brought up to its capacity or anything like it.

I would draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the qualifications of the teacher. This is the usual observation made at most of our schools. On the whole, our teachers are not as well qualified as they should be, and we get recommendations very often from the Inspectors that these teachers should be sent away to receive Normal training.
