Extract from report of Inspector E. L. Fuller on the Samson Day School, dated Nov. 20th, 1925. Original on file 112-7-6.

"Miss Logan is meeting with fair success. She has not the special training actually required for teaching Indian children. Not enough attention has been paid to teaching the children items of general information which are not found in the course of study. Good progress cannot be made until the children have a 'grounding' in that general knowledge which the average English speaking pupil acquires from his everyday experiences before entering school.

"One of the essential needs of Indian schools is teachers who are especially qualified both by experience and inherent ability. A good instructor must have a good grounding in the subject of psychology particularly as it applies to Indian children. A few extra dollars spent in securing this type of teacher would in the end prove to be an economy.

"As already noted, I would recommend that the teacher give instruction with a view to fixing in the minds of her junior pupils those items of general information necessary for an intelligent acquisition of the subject matter outlined in the course of study. The subject of Reading should be strongly stressed. Three or four short lessons a day would not be too much with Indian children who are entering school."

Dear Sir,

About eleven months ago Miss Nightingale who was acting as boys' matron in this institute had her hand poisoned and was taken to the general hospital in the city. Through the excellent surgical, medical and hospital treatment she received her life was saved. It was necessary to amputate her right arm at the elbow. This institution has cared for her and looked after her interests believing that under the circumstances an obligation rested upon us. She has been here for some time recuperating and her health is in very good condition. On account of her handicap however, and other reasons, I think it would not do to have her here permanently. She is a bright, intelligent woman and very good in handling small children. While she is not a certified teacher, I believe she would do excellent work in an Indian day school on a Reserve. Madam:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant.

In reply I beg to inform you that the Department does not supply rations to Indian day schools. We would, however, supply certain provisions for the purpose of furnishing the pupils with a midday lunch. These supplies usually consist of flour, rice, beef, tea, sugar, salt and baking powder. I may say that supplies of this nature are only furnished to schools where the teachers undertake to prepare and serve a lunch to the children at midday. We will write Mr. Agent Askey and request him to purchase and deliver a quantity of the above supplies if you will undertake to prepare a midday lunch for the pupils. He will also be instructed, if the purchase is made, to deliver these supplies at the school.

The janitor's duties consist of sweeping and cleaning the schoolroom each day, scrubbing the same at least once a month, lighting the fires in due time in the morning to have the school-room heated when the pupils arrive, and attending to any snow shovelling that may be required.

The Department does not supply clothing to school children except in cases of orphan and destitute children specially recommended by the Agent.

In future it would be well if you would direct enquiries, first, to the local Indian Agent, and if you receive no satisfaction, to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Dear Mr. Graham,

Samson's Day School.

This school has been taught by Miss Sweet, who lives just outside the reserve. She however, informed me that she was resigning - her resignation to take effect the 30th of June. There were twenty-four children on the register, but at the time of my visit, there were five girls and seven boys present. Most of the children are in the first grade, five being in the second grade and four in the third. The average attendance has been approximately ten. The teacher informed me that it was very discouraging work on account of the irregular attendance. Naturally a child coming two or three days and then staying home one or two, does not make very rapid progress. This, however, is not Miss Sweet's fault, as she is quite a capable girl, and has given good service. I might add that the children who have attended at all regularly have advanced very well in their studies.

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Sir,

In your report on the Samson's Indian Day School for the month of January, last, you stated as follows: "I am trying to get a larger attendance, but am not receiving much assistance from Miss Fairservice." This matter was drawn to her attention and she was informed that it was part of the teacher's duties to encourage the children in their attendance in every way possible and that she should use every effort on her part to that end.

A reply has been received from Miss Fairservice in which she takes exception to your statement. She states that she takes a deep interest in the children attending the school and that, upon her arrival, she drove around the reserve in company with Rev. R. C. Taylor and visited the homes of the parents who were not sending their children to school and she has also given you a list of the children who failed to attend.

The attendance at this school is very irregular and it might be well for you to again inform the parents that it is expected that their children will attend regularly. In cases where they refuse or neglect to send their children to school, it might be well to take action under Section 11 of the Indian Act, as amended at the last session of Parliament, and prosecute the worst offenders.

The teacher has also complained about the condition of the biscuits supplied. She states that on opening some of the boxes she found they had been badly damaged by the mice and were not fit for use.

She has also complained about the wood supplied and that, as it has not been properly cut for use, the school-room has been very cold and she claims that as a result she developed bronchitis.

In January, last, an account was forwarded by you for four cords of firewood and three tons of coal. It is not understood why there should be complaints regarding the fuel. You should take these matters up with the teacher and make satisfactory arrangements regarding the fuel and the biscuits.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Just a line to bring reference to salary paid for teaching in an Indian Day School. This I am told is $60.00 per month. Now in view of the increasing high cost of living you will agree that this is entirely inadequate.

Again you are no doubt aware that in white schools the minimum salary is $820.00 per annum. This is paid not only to those holding a certificate but also to those teaching on permit.

In Alberta at least, the teachers are united in demanding and are getting a salary commensurate with the H.C.I. living. Now I think I will be quite in order when I say that it is true the salary was increased in Indian Schools and that the pre-war wage is not enough. This will mean less difficulty in getting suitable teachers for our Indian schools.
You will agree that there are not as many attractions in an Indian School as there are in a white school. In the first place you are isolated and more or less in contact with Indians only. To one who may not speak the language this is not very attractive.

Again your work is more exacting as the progress of the pupils is so slow as at times to be almost discouraging.

I would like to know when and what bonus you pay for teaching. I received one cheque for $20.60. In what amount? Do you forward it on receipt?

Please take this matter up with the Dept. and advise me what is being done. I think the salaries ought to be retrospective till Oct. 1918 if any increase is considered. Thanking you for favor asked.

Yours very sincerely,

Roy L. Taylor.

Dear Sir,

Some time ago I wrote to the agent regarding my salary and never received an answer.

For five years I have been receiving a little over $1 per month for teaching the Samson Day School, which I have found a very small sum to get along on since everything costs so much now.

I live five miles from the school and take a lunch with me. I also have a horse to keep.

My father died a little over a year ago and since then two of my brothers have gone to the front, so that I have expenses to meet now that I did not have before, and that my salary will hardly allow for.

which are the months which I asked for to have it closed) and for me to kindly open the school at the proper date after the holidays. I cannot see how I can do it; it is unreasonable to ask it.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant in which you ask me to state what changes are necessary to secure a regular attendance of pupils at the Samson's day school. My view is that regular attendance can only be secured through compulsion. Under the existing conditions I think the expenditure is largely a waste of funds and energy. It is necessary for White children to attend classes regularly for about 10 years to gain an ordinary education. Whites have an advantage over the Indians for the tuition is in a language, generally at least, spoken and understood from babyhood. My impression is that if the records of this school are compiled for the last 3 years that the most regular attendants were not present 1/3 of the days the school was in operation.

I hesitate, however, with regard to advising coercive measures, until adequate provision has been provided to receive the children. At this point a new and up-to-date class room, with a kitchen and refectory attached, and a cottage & a stable for the use of the teacher would be required. I would ask the Indians to set aside about 160 acres of land for school purposes. My reason for suggesting such a large area of land is because at some future date it might be thought expedient.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
expedient to provide and operate some other kind of a school than the one herein suggested. In such an event there would be sufficient land for pasture, farming and gardening and the buildings on the ground could then be used for some purpose.

If the Department has decided to continue an industrial school, at Red Deer or at some other point in Northern Alta., the children from this day school ought to be transferred to the industrial school, on attaining the age of say 14 years, for a 3 year term.

The day school should be, I think, in charge of a qualified male teacher, married and without a family. About an acre of land might be under cultivation in connection with this day school so that the teacher would be in a position to practically demonstrate the growing of flowers and garden stuff in this acre plot during the summer months.

The cost of the buildings, fences, well, &c., would be between $5000. and $5500.00. I would not expect to secure a competent teacher for this post for less than $75.00 per month and then on the assurance that this salary would be advanced to $83.33 per month after a 2 year term and there was abundant evidence of proficiency.

The curriculum of Indian schools require revision, I think. If the present generation of Indians are educated in ethics and the masses advanced to about Standard IV, i.e., speak, read, write fair English and compute ordinary business transactions, the Department would then have discharged its duty towards the Indians along educational lines.

My notion is that the young male Indians should be encouraged to take up diversified farming for a livelihood and the young females tutored along such lines as will best fit them to become helpful wives to Indian farmers. I have stated on several occasions that the class books in use in Indian schools do not, in my opinion, meet the requirements of the pupils, say for Indian children after they have
have passed standard 2 readers, or standard 3, anyway.

The opinion I have held is that every line of reading matter should be instructive on ethics and the gaining of an honourable livelihood in after life.

Regarding the so called Industrial schools I entertain the view that of late they seem to me striving to make sufficient to meet expenses to too great a degree. When they are compelled to do this too little class & demonstration work is carried on. Last week I visited the St. Joseph's school (Dunbow) and there has been no class work by the boys since June last at this institution. Gardening, haying, harvesting and threshing has been the occupation of the staff and the male pupils for over 4 months. Class work likely was resumed by the boys today. The girls have received regular tuition, however. I shall likely make up a report of this inspection to-morrow and have simply referred to this to illustrate my statement "that industrial schools seemed to me to be striving too much now to meet the expenses of operation".

The vacation, too, should be at a time when it best met the local conditions.

Yours obediently,

Sir,

I regret to inform you that the Department has not been able to make arrangements for the erection of the temporary day school building on the Samson's Reserve and the matter will, therefore, have to stand over for the present. No action should be taken of course to sink a well.

The Department will, however, retain the services of Miss Barner as field matron. Miss Barner will be expected to devote her efforts to the improvement of the home life of the Indians on the reserve. She should visit their homes, giving practical instruction in plain cooking, washing, sewing, the cutting, mending and making over of garments, ventilation, cleanliness, home treatment of common diseases and rules for the treatment of emergency cases as well as other branches of knowledge essential to the proper management of the home, special attention being paid to sanitation and cleanliness. She should also extend any help she may be able to young mothers in the care of their children. Miss Barner will be expected to furnish monthly reports showing the visits made and work performed with any general remarks that may be considered necessary. Memorandum for Mr. Scott

The situation of the present school is suitable for that Band and a portion of the Montana Band, the difficulty however is to secure regular attendance with the opposition of Chief Samson to a day school.

Several of the Indian houses are a short distance from the present site and more will probably be built owing to the removal of those who were on the surrendered portion.

During the summer a considerable number including Samson himself camped within a half a mile of the present school, so that there is not distance that affects the attendance.

A day school with boarding annex so that the scholars could be brought and returned home is I think the best solution of the attendance problem. If properly explained to Samson and built near his house he might be satisfied.

It would also be suitable for Louis Bull's people who now have no school, and would be midway between Louis Bull's and the most distant of Samsons.
Good water would be a consideration and a deep well would have to be drilled. The plans are attached showing the approximate position of the houses on each reserve.

Louis Bull is 6 miles from Sauernes House and the most distant of Sauernes people are about the same.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 12th instant No. 117199 re a Day School at Samson's Reserve, Alberta, I beg to say that the experiment of a Day School has been tried on this Reserve and under some of the most faithful and devoted teachers that we have ever employed, but with very poor success.

My own conviction is that nothing will satisfy Samson but a Boarding School, and this, I think, as was been pointed out in previous correspondence, would be very undesirable as long as the Red Deer School is open. I do not know if it is Indian Agent Mann's intention that Mr. Steinhauer should teach the school, but if so, I beg to say that he has abundant work in the discharge of his duties as missionary without undertaking the additional part of school teaching. If the experiment of a Day School is to be tried with any chance of success then it is essential that the Department undertake forthwith to provide the necessary appliances and make such provision for bringing the more distant children and furnishing them with a warm meal at noon as will help to overcome the reluctance of the Chief and their parents to have them attend anything but a Boarding School.

If the Department takes up heartily the most approved methods we will do all in our power to co-operate, first in the way of influencing the parents through the labors of the missionary, and secondly by trying to find and submit to the Government the names of well qualified teachers; but if this last effort is to be

I have always wanted a boarding school like the Roman Catholics have. I cannot support the Red Deer School in any way. I have asked my people to not place their children in the Roman Catholic School until next fall, so that we may know what the Government and Church are going to do for us. If a Boarding School is not assured by that time I will tell the people to send them if they like. We do not want a Day School, for we need somewhere to leave our children when we go away.'

but we are not going to send them off the Reserve when there is a school on the Reserve.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 14th instant, I regret very much that the statement made in the report to the Indian Department should have been misleading. I stated that after November the 15th, the morning session was changed from 9 to 9.30, owing to the fact that the pupils could not get there any sooner during short days in winter, especially those who were some distance from the school, and did not repeat naming the hours in the afternoon session, for they were the same, there was no change made. I suppose I ought to have explained more fully that after three o'clock I usually practise the children in singing, drill or give some religious instructions, for the school always closes at four o'clock, and has ever since I came to the Reserve. I find this practice very helpful in getting the pupils to speak more loudly and promptly.

Now regarding the reports, I always wrote the required number for the Indian agent to sign and send to the Department, and a copy for the missionary to sign and send to the Mission Rooms. Why they have not been sent I cannot explain unless that Rev. German our late missionary here, may probably have intended keeping them until the close of the year and sending them then, but may have forgotten. I entrusted it entirely to him. However I have kept some copies which I will send, and also the last report as you desired. In the future I shall forward them myself.

I am very sorry that anyone should be led to think I have not
been faithful regarding the duties of the school, for I have always tried to do all in my power to promote the interests of this school, and my work has not been confined to the school alone, but also to the homes of the community. I regret that Rev. German is no longer here, who could give you a good report of the work done, but I should like to refer you to Mr. Grant our Indian Agent who visits the school regularly and will be able to tell you all about it.

Certainly the work is often very discouraging, as the parents are very often obliged to go away hunting or fishing, taking the children with them which makes the average seem very low, but they are gone for weeks at a time. Then too there is so much sickness often diseases that are contagious. While they are here their progress is splendid.

Were it not that we who are engaged in the Indian work have entrusted all to the control of a Higher Power, the discouragements the loneliness would often seem too great to be borne, but we also take courage when we remember that our friends are upholding us in prayer.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) S. Klippert.

P. S. I was thinking that probably some one else might be more capable of taking this work than I, and while I know it is difficult to find any one willing to engage in the Indian work, I would continue until the end of this term, and if you could in the meantime secure another I would very willingly resign. I felt that I had been led to take up this work, and trust that I have not brought dishonor upon the cause of God.
Ottawa, March 6, 1906.

The work of the teacher is not capped at every turn. In the summer they are away making hay and in the winter they are away on hunting expeditions for two weeks or a month at a time. They almost invariably take their families with them so that the work of the teacher suffers in consequence. They are not only away but they are not properly cared for and this is shown in their inability to pay attention to their work when they do come to school. Under such conditions no real progress is impossible. The only solution to this difficult problem is that a small boarding school be erected.
To be sure, that hope will be there will be some chance for the teacher to see the results of his labor. There are also some families living altogether out of reach of the day school who would send their children to a boarding school but as they are now situated the children scarcely see the inside of a school.

Frustrating that these requests will help to guide the Department in making its decision.

Sir,

In compliance with your letter No II2-7-5, dated the 14th instant. I beg to state that I consulted the Teacher of Samson's Day School with reference to the supplying of a mid-day meal for the pupils. The Teacher informed me that she was not prepared to supply a mid-day lunch, unless the present arrangement were not satisfactory.

Your letter dated March 1st, 1923, No. II2-7-5, authorized beef, flour, rice, and baking powder, and with the exception of the flour and baking powder (biscuits being used instead) these have been supplied from the Warehouse here to both Louis Bull's and Samson's Day Schools for the mid-day meal, during the past year. As Samson's Day School is held in a portion of the Methodist Church building there are no facilities for cooking, and the lunch during the year has been prepared for the pupils by Mrs. Taylor at the Mission house, without expense to the Department.

The supplies for this lunch have been sent to the school from here on Saturdays with the Farming Instructor of the Samson Reserve.

With regard to the janitor's services, I might say that I have instructed the Janitor as regards his work and informed the Teacher at the beginning of each term as to what

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

Ottawa.
what work was required of him, asking her to let me know at the end of each quarter as to how the work was performed before I would voucher for his pay. The attached is a Certificate sent to me by the Teacher for the quarter ended December 1923 and from it I understood the janitor was performing his work satisfactorily. As the School is six miles from the Agency it is impossible for me to keep in touch daily, and in this matter more co-operation on the part of the teacher would be of assistance.

The above matters will have my continued careful attention and which I trust will be satisfactory.

I am Sir,

Sir:

As it has now been definitely decided to erect a Day School on the Samson Indian Reserve No. 137, at this Agency, it will now be necessary for me to estimate in my 1943-4 Estimates for provisions for mid-day meals for the pupils attending this School.

As this is a new departure, I would be grateful if I may be supplied with a list of provisions issued to Day Schools, and the quantities allowed per pupil.

It is also presumed that coal and wood for this School and the teacher's house will have to be estimated for. Is this correct, please?

Any information you can give me as to approximate quantities of supplies required by Day Schools which it is necessary for me to estimate for for the next fiscal year will be of great help and guidance. I presume that all supplies for the balance of this fiscal year will be looked after from our Branch at Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the possible establishment of a day school on the Samson Indian Reserve.

The erection of a day school is contingent on the British Columbia Security Commission's taking over certain residential schools. As yet no definite decision has been made in the latter regard.

Our purpose in sending Mr. Doucet to the Hobbema Agency, to consider a possible site for a day school, is due to the fact that he was in the West and we thought that it would be advisable to have complete information available, in the event of its being finally decided to establish a day school.

As soon as a definite decision is made regarding the matter you will be further advised. In any event, it would not be necessary for you to include an amount for this day school in your agency estimates, as the money provided for the day schools throughout Canada is included in a lump sum.

Yours truly,

Mr. A.G.B. Lewis,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.

Superintendent of Education:

Purchase of Robbema Public School:

On this date with Mr. Supt. Woodsworth, I went over the school building and grounds which are offered for sale by the Ponoka School Division for $6,000 with the hope that Metis children will share the facilities thus made available. Their presence is not desired in the white schools.

There is stated to be over three acres of ground, most of which has been cleared, levelled and is grass-covered—one of the best playgrounds I have seen.

There is no well on the premises, water being obtained from a shallow well in the yard of a house one hundred feet away.

Electric power has been carried to the house above.

The highway from Edmonton to Calgary passes the school.

Inside the school is 32 ft. long and 22 ft. wide. The main classroom is 23' by 22' with 50 ft. of blackboard and six feet of display board. The floors are of hardwood and are in good condition. The adjoining "activity" room, visible through a glass partition, is 9' by 12' and is well supplied with cupboards.

The movable furniture and the library books are not offered for sale. We will have to supply teacher's and pupils' desks, books and all the usual supplies. Local officials should at an early date supply Ottawa with the number of children in each grade who are to be admitted to this school in September so that supplies and equipment may be made available in sufficient time before opening-day.

There is a full basement containing a good furnace, two cloakrooms (each with a toilet-bowl of the yeast type) and a washstand for general use. The toilets are stated to have given trouble-free service. They appear to be in good condition and are odorless at this time.

Altogether the installation is a bargain at the asking price, and I fully support the recommendation that it be purchased.

In the afternoon we attended a Board meeting of the Ponoka School Division. Present also were Mr. Ross, the local school superintendent, and Dr. Swift, deputy minister of the Alberta Dept. of Education.

The other party to the agreement into which it is suggested that the Dominion Government enter would be the Board of School Trustees of the Ponoka School Division (Secretary DeForest Nelson) and not, as in the case of the recent negotiations in Manitoba, the Provincial Government.

I described the terms on which we have contributed to the capital cost and operating expenses of schools where Indian and white pupils are educated together. I did not suggest that we would require from the Ponoka Board a contribution toward capital cost because, privately, I think that what we are saving on construction cost might be reckoned as more than covering any contribution for which they would be liable.
Operating costs were discussed at greater length. Those present agreed to consider the school a thirty-five pupil school. It is almost certain that there will be five Metis attending during the first year of operation; there could be ten such pupils, and I warned the Board that the proportion of Metis could increase sharply if the Director's instructions to Supt. Woodsworth (to eject trespassers) are fully carried out (see letter 754-1 (R.T.) 26 October, 1948), or if, to qualify for Family Allowances, additional Metis were to move in. The members of the Board appeared, however, to be reconciled to the early prospect of paying from fifteen to thirty per cent. of the operating costs which, I also warned them, were likely to be higher than those obtaining in some small schools because the Dominion Government makes no charge to Indians for anything connected with schools.

Dr. Swift read from the Alberta Schools Act to show that in calculating costs to be charged when one school district received pupils from another, the following items only are to be included:

- Salary of teacher and janitor
- Cost of classroom supplies used during the year
- Cost of light, heat and water consumed

To these I think we should add (and mention in the draft agreement to be offered to the Board) maintenance and repairs for this particular building. It will have to be re-decorated in a lighter colour within a year or two.

The digging of a well and the extending of the powerline seem to be more our responsibility as capital costs linked with the construction of two more rooms and a teachersage on the same land.

I stated that as a majority of the Indians who are likely to attend are adherents of the Roman Catholic Church certain provisions of the Indian Act apply. There was no objection made, but Mr. Ross, who inspects the Ermineskins Residential School, expressed the hope that only certificated schoolteachers would be considered for appointment.

There was one other factor that I thought worth mentioning. The Parliamentary Committee recommended that Indian children be educated wherever possible along with white children. They made no recommendation for setting up "Jim Crow" establishments as some people might call the proposed arrangement. I intimated that the opinion of the Alberta Indian Association might be sought.

The Board secretary is to send the account for the purchase of the school to Mr. Supt. Woodsworth in the near future.

C.A.F. Clark,
G.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Superintendent of Education:

Hobbema Day School:

With Mr. Supt. Woodsworth I again visited this school on Friday, June 10, particularly to see the Metis pupils who attend and to inspect their cumulative record cards.

On this occasion there was only one Metis present, a son of Daniel Spence who lives on a nearby road-allowance.

The teacher told me that she does not keep cumulative record cards for elementary pupils. It seems to be the rare one-room school in the western provinces which maintains these records in the manner presumably expected.

The teacher reassured us that the school has always been comfortably warm. She stated that the lighting, however, is poor on dull days.

When the school closes at the end of June she intends to devote herself to her domestic duties.

Later we toured the Metis areas, questioning the adults whom we found at home. Present indications are that there may be six Metis children likely to attend in September.

It might be advisable to declare to all concerned now that (if this school is purchased) that attendance for the next year will be restricted to those children within walking distance whose parents at recent treaty-payment declared themselves adherents of the Roman Catholic Church. This will allow the Ermineskin School to make early arrangements regarding discharges and admissions for next year.

The Superintendent might soon prepare a list of the homes in the above category which he considers that this day school could conveniently serve so as to provide thirty Indian pupils.

C.A.F. Clark

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hobbema Indian Day School.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room Indian day school on the Montana Indian Reserve, Hobbema Indian Agency.

Originally, it was our intention to erect a new school, but due to negotiations between our field officials, we have been offered a school building and grounds being vacated by the Ponoka School Division.

This school building and its contents are described by our Educational Survey Officer as follows:

"There is stated to be over three acres of ground, most of which has been cleared, levelled and is grass-covered - one of the best playgrounds I have seen.

"There is no well on the premises, water being obtained from a shallow well in the yard of a house one hundred feet away. Electric power has been carried to the house above. The highway from Edmonton to Calgary passes the school.

"Inside the school is 32 ft. long and 22 ft. wide. The main classroom is 23' by 22' with 30 ft. of blackboard and six feet of display board. The floors are of hardwood and are in good condition. The adjoining 'activity' room, visible through a glass partition, is 9' by 12' and is well supplied with cupboards.

..................................

"There is a full basement containing a good furnace, two cloakrooms (each with a toilet-bowl
of the yeast type) and a washstand for general use. The toilets are stated to have given trouble-free service. They appear to be in good condition and are odourless at this time.

"Altogether the installation is a bargain at the asking price, and I fully support the recommendation that it be purchased."

This is a stucco school, and the total price for the building, three acres of land, coal-shed, tables, chairs and coal is $6,163.00. Mr. Indian Superintendent Woodsworth and Mr. Regional Supervisor Gooderham both recommend the purchase of this school at the price indicated, and I have prepared a submission to Council accordingly.

This school would be attended by Roman Catholic children presently attending the Hobbema Residential School. There are now at least seventy-five children of school age, mostly of the Roman Catholic faith, for whom there are no school facilities. The Ponoka School Division is erecting a consolidated school and, therefore, have no further need of this building. It is ideally situated for about thirty pupils who can walk daily to it. The Provincial Department of Education has also requested that we admit five or six Metis children for whom they will pay the regular tuition rates.

I CONCUR IN THIS RECOMMENDATION

Ottawa, April 23, 1949.

The Deputy Minister of Justice,
Ottawa.

Re: Orders in Council authorising the purchase of land or payment of compensation for expropriated land.

Dear Sir -

Orders in Council authorising the acquisition of land almost invariably require that a good title, free from all encumbrances, be acquired as a condition precedent to payment of the purchase moneys. It frequently appears, upon title to land being searched by agents of the Minister of Justice, that the vendor's title is subject to a reservation in respect of mines or minerals or to easements or encroachments which do not affect the use of the land for which it is being acquired. In such cases, it has, in the past, been necessary to have the Order in Council amended to permit the purchase price to be paid for the land subject to the reservation, encumbrance or encroachments.

To avoid delays and inconvenience, I suggest, for your consideration, that, when authority is being sought from the Governor in Council for such transactions, the Report to Council should be so framed as to seek authority to pay the purchase money upon obtaining a good title free from all encumbrances, reservations or encroachments other than such encumbrances, reservations or encroachments as, in the opinion of your Minister, do not affect the use of the land for the purpose for which it is being acquired.

Yours truly,

(sgd) W. R. Jackett,
Asst. Deputy Minister.

The Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,

LIGHTING ENGINEER
The following lighting recommendation has been prepared from information which you forwarded to us.

The lighting, if installed according to this plan and specifications will meet with the approval of the Department of Education.

Classroom Lighting and Study Room

The blueprint shows the necessary locations of the fixtures to produce uniform lighting. The various types are described in the attached Appendix.

Fluorescent lighting possesses some advantages over incandescent lighting and is recommended as first choice. Its first cost is higher but its power consumption is much less than incandescent lighting.

Of the two incandescent types indirect lighting is recommended in preference to general diffuse because of its freedom from glare and its soft distribution, provided that the fixtures and lamps will be kept clean and the ceiling will not be allowed to become dirty or discoloured.

It is particularly suited in this case also because of the lower than average ceiling height. The glare from enclosing globes would be excessive.

APPENDIX TO SCHOOL LIGHTING REPORT

This appendix forms an essential part of the lighting recommendation

GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS

Benefits of Adequate Lighting

The necessity of adequate lighting in classrooms has been thoroughly established by scientific research and by actual experience. The cost of installing a good lighting system is small compared to the benefits accruing from it. Some of these benefits are: minimized eye strain, clear seeing from all parts of the room, increased efficiency of teacher, independence of variations in daylight, better progress and fewer examination failures, greater benefits to pupils with subnormal eyes, better discipline, and more cheerful surroundings.

Requirements of the System

The principal requirements of classroom lighting are that it shall provide evenly distributed illumination of adequate intensity for all desks, with sharp shadows minimized and with the least possible glare.

Types of Lighting

There are three types of lighting that may be used for classrooms. The selection will be influenced chiefly by the cost of the fixtures, the provision for cleaning them regularly, and the maintenance of the ceiling in good reflecting condition.

Indirect Tungsten Lighting. See Plate 2, groups 1 and 2

This is produced by projecting light to the ceiling from which it is distributed throughout the room. Consequently the ceiling MUST be maintained in a highly reflective condition: white or near white.

If the fixtures are of the OPEN type, units 1, 3, 4 and 5 of group 1, Plate 2, or those of group 2, they will collect considerable dust which will necessitate frequent cleaning. Unit No. 2, group 1 uses a BOWL-SILVERED lamp in which the reflector is deposited upon the inside of the bulb where dust cannot collect. Therefore, a reasonable accumulation of dust will not seriously reduce their efficiency. This is a decided advantage.

The quality of properly designed and installed indirect lighting is excellent - softly diffused light that is beneficial to the eyes.
Semi-direct Tungsten Lighting. See Plate 2, group 4.

This lighting is produced by enclosing-glass units; No. 1, group 4 is of prismatic glass; units 2 to 5 are of white or milk glass. White glass units to comply with these recommendations must be greater in diameter than in depth.

Semi-direct fixtures are satisfactory if they are of the specified size and shape, and suspended at the specified height.

The lighting is somewhat less refined in quality than indirect, but does not depreciate quite as rapidly from the accumulation of dust or discoloration of the ceiling.

Fluorescent Lighting.

This is much more efficient than tungsten and will produce twice or more as much light for the same amount of power. It has advantages for high intensity lighting. Fixtures with bare lamps fully exposed are not suitable for classrooms.

In school the pupils spend a considerable amount of time looking straight ahead at the blackboard or the teacher. If bare lamps are exposed to view the glare may be objectionable.

When fluorescent lighting is to be used on 25 cycle power, the utmost care is needed in the selection of fixtures that will minimize the flicker that is caused by the 25 cycle power.

Relative Cost.

Fluorescent lighting is higher in first cost than tungsten lighting, particularly in 25 cycle districts. Indirect tungsten is next, and semi-direct tungsten the lowest.

Blackboard Lighting.

It is most important that all the pupils be able to see distinctly the work that is written on the blackboards. Most blackboards reflect glaring light that prevents clear seeing.

The most effective way of overcoming this is to shade the windows that admit the glaring light and illuminate the blackboards by supplementary units installed especially for the purpose.

Maintenance.

All lighting fixtures collect dust, particularly indirect open type fixtures of any kind. Dust absorbs and wastes light. This wasted light is paid for but not received. Cleaning of lighting equipment is just as necessary to a lighting system as lubrication to an automobile.
Maintenance (Cont'd)

Do not let the ceiling become dull with age. Dark ceilings increase glare and reduce the efficiency of the lighting.

Allowance for Depreciation.

In the preparation of this recommendation an allowance has been made for natural depreciation of the lamps and the accumulation of dust on the lighting equipment between cleaning periods. The lighting will therefore appear higher in intensity when the system is new than it will after a few months' use.

Wiring.

The importance of adequate wiring is evident from the fact that a 10% voltage loss, due to inadequate current-carrying capacity, will cause a light loss of approximately 24%. The minimum wire size is noted on the drawing. This size is based on a maximum voltage loss of 2%, which is in accordance with good wiring practice. (In no case should wire smaller than No. 12 B & S Gauge be used for branch circuits).

Window Shades.

Attention is directed to the proper use of window shades. They are installed particularly to shield the desks near the windows from direct sunlight.

It is only under the MOST favourable conditions that the desks farthest from the windows receive fair daylight illumination. When the window shades are drawn over the upper half of the windows, the illumination on desks farthest from the windows may be decreased 60% or more, depending upon the local conditions.

Conclusion.

This plan has been carefully prepared for this particular school. Emphasis is placed on the importance of providing lighting in accordance with present-day standards. REDUCTION OF THE NUMBER OF FIXTURES, OR THE SUBSTITUTION OF SMALLER LAMPS OR INFERIOR LIGHTING EQUIPMENT WILL RESULT IN INFERIOR LIGHTING THAT WILL NOT PRODUCE THE DESIRED RESULTS. The following steps are necessary in order to take full advantage of the benefits of better lighting.

1. Install the lighting outlets as indicated.
2. Insist on adequate wiring with wire sizes shown on the drawing.
3. Install only mogul-socket fixtures for classroom lighting (for tungsten lamps).
4. Select the type and size of fixture specified.
5. All electrical work must be approved by your District Electrical Inspector.

We desire to put up a small building near the school teacher's residence on the Hobbema Reserve in which the school may be taught during the coming winter, and where a few scholars who live at too great a distance to go back and forth every day may reside during the school week. We had obtained a price from Mr. Fee of Wetaskiwin of $570.00 which was afterwards increased to $600.00, but we understood this offer to be for the erection of the school by day labor with himself as foreman. It afterwards appeared that he was acting for Mr. S.H. Reist, a contractor of Wetaskiwin, and the intention was to pay the lump sum of $600.00 for the building erected from plans and specifications which had been approved. This slight misunderstanding delayed the matter and the telegram of September 23rd which I prepared was not sent.

I think it important that this small building should be erected immediately. The Minister has the authority under the provisions of the Public Works' Act to make arrangements for the construction of works without public tender under certain conditions. The condition which governs in this case is "Cases where the estimated cost of the work is less than $5,000 and appears to the Minister, in view of the nature of the work, that it is not advisable to invite tenders." The work may also be considered as one of pressing emergency as the present school buildings are
at an inconvenient distance from the school teacher's residence and extremely cold in winter weather. I would, therefore, recommend that Ministerial authority be obtained to carry out the arrangement.

Colonel Neary:

Hobema Superintendent,
Baptist Mission and school on the Montana Reserve:

With Mr. T.G. McLeod I went to the m/n reserve on May 16, proceeding part of the way by truck, finishing the journey across flooded areas in a wagon drawn by a team supplied by a white farmer, Mr. Bill Davis of Ponoka.

In the accompanying photo Mr. McLeod is shown seated in the Baptist church-school. At his left are Miss Twila Bartz and Miss Cecilia Priebe.

Miss Bartz is an American college graduate with a teaching certificate from North Dakota. Miss Priebe is not a certificated teacher. They state their denomination as the North American (formerly it was "German") Baptist Church — baptism of adults by complete immersion — with headquarters at Forest Park, Illinois. They have, indeed, a closer depot, The Christian Training Institute in Edmonton. The head thereof is the Rev. F.W. Benke whose address is 10231 96th St., Edmonton.

These young ladies started in Edmonton during the winter and resumed their work on the reserve about April 25.

The building which they used was erected by the denomination primarily as a church. Comfortable living quarters are included at the back. They use water from a creek, boiling it, of course. I also saw the place where they began work — a little log cabin owned by an Indian named Standing-in-the-road. Living quarters consisted of a trailer which is still standing in the yard.

They have an enrolment of nine pupils with an average attendance of eight. The denominational status of these children is as confirmed and it is at Louis Bull.

They seem to have obtained sufficient school supplies at church expense. What they want mostly is official recognition.

I had an unexpected conversation with the Rev. Mr. Benke. He took the seat beside me on the train from Nordegg to Rocky Mountain House (he had been working among the Indians) and knowing that a school at Bighorn was under consideration, he tried to supply a teacher. I told him that the position might eventually be advertised. At a previous meeting with the Indians they told me that they wanted the school "Protestant". They have a Methodist-United Church tradition.

C.A.F. Clark

Re: Montana Day School

For your information, I beg to report the Montana Day School will be in operation during the coming winter.

The missionary teacher is Mr. Newman, a veteran of the last war, and having seen service in Italy and elsewhere. He and his wife and two children are accommodating themselves in the rear of the church and are building an addition before winter. I have met them, and find them to be most suitable.

At the dedication of the Church, on October 10th, the children who have been in attendance at the school for the past year or two, gave an impressive demonstration of what they have been taught. Children ten and twelve years old spoke in perfect English. A year ago, some of these children could not speak a word of English, like their parents, and usually presented a fairly primitive appearance.

As the presence of this school involves such matters as payment of Family Allowances and general administration, I would be glad of your comments. I am sure it would be very difficult for the Department to get teachers to labor and live among the Indians as these people do. I would suggest that some aid be given to the school, say in the form of scribblers and readers. I am sure that they will be welcome and well used.

(sgd.) H. N. Woodsworth,

With reference to your 112-2-1 (E) of the 27th December 1948, addressed to the Reverend George Dorey, D.D., Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, I have read the copy sent to this office, and I am sure it is a step toward solving some of our administration problems regarding the existence of the school at this Agency. 7. Should I have the children attending this school authorized by the Department?

8. Being a day school, the children require a hot noon lunch which they do not bring. At present the Missionary is supplying this.

Attached please find copies of a document handed to me by a group of the Montana Indians about a month ago which has some bearing on this school. This church school has the support of the majority of the Montana Band, but in my opinion the distance some children have to go is too great.

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary

Re: Baptist Mission Day School
Montana Reserve, Hobbema Indian Agency

With reference to your 112-2-1 (E) of 10th January, 1949, I beg to submit a list of those at present enrolled at the Baptist Mission school, Montana Reserve. There are ten in regular attendance and a potential ten more who have applied to go. Of these ten, the majority are going to the Edmonton Indian Residential School and some to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

Before three interpreters, the Resident Nurse, the Farm Instructor and myself, nearly all the Montana Indians claim to adhere to the teaching and doctrines of the Baptist church.

Mr. R. Neuman has a grade IX standing, plus three years education at a Baptist College in Edmonton, which I am informed, has a good standing in Educational circles. He is a veteran of six years service with the army and was in the First Division serving in Italy. He seems to be as well qualified as any teacher on the Hobbema Indian Agency. It is hoped that all teachers, regardless of religious denomination, be at least of normal standing in the near future.

Good work is being done by Mr. Neuman and wife since their arrival. They have organized sewing clubs among the Indian women, feed their pupils a noon meal, plan to plant a school garden this spring, and in general are carrying out a program of education which as a whole is showing results, and such that no other church organization has done to date, due to the fact that they are in close contact with the Indians as family units.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

Re: Savings, School Pupils
Hobbema Indian Agency

With reference to your 94-112 (T-3) of March 10, and to your comments regarding the present policy of allowing a child to withdraw his savings as soon as he is discharged from School. I readily concur with your suggestion that the savings be kept until the individual attains the age of twenty-one years or marries, as a general policy. I am continually amazed however, at specific cases of young people of seventeen or over who have exhibited mature judgement in the spending of their savings. There is the case of Marcella Lightning who applied all her savings this year to buying a sewing machine and even went to work at a white farmers in order to make up the difference. At present, I have a girl (Maria Wildcat) recently discharged from the Ermeliekin School, who has decided not to withdraw her savings until she can get $60.00 or more to enable her to purchase a sewing machine. She is working for various white people to try to attain this end. This girl is also needed at home to aid her widowed mother support a large family. At the conference of Superintendents in Canada last April, this matter was discussed. At that time, it was pointed out and to which I agree, that the critical period of an Indian life is from the time he leaves school until he gets his feet. He or she is released from discipline into a world of low standards and he must adjust to cope with this situation, without further aid or guidance.

I am continually appalled by the lack of opportunities for the Indians on this Agency. They live in the centre of one of Canada's wealthiest areas and near enlightened centres, yet over a hundred and possibly one hundred and fifty children will never be able to attend School. As you are aware, no school has been built on this Agency since 1890. I see children of people whom I have known since birth sinking gradually into poverty and ignorance as a result. The children who can not find facilities in school are getting married, legally or otherwise, at the ages of 14 years to 18 years. They provide a great problem and I suggest that any arrangement regarding saving this group should be kept in mind. I would appreciate receiving specific instructions as outlined above, and in the meantime, will discourage any further withdrawals. In the case of Barney Montour, I will inform him and his parents that he will have to keep his savings until he marries or attains the age of 21 years. For your information, he is helping his father on a successful farm.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

The Supt. then explained to the Chief, that Major Clark from the Educational Branch would be at the Hobbema Agency in May to look over and report on the Day School situation, and he would like the Chief and Indians interested in a Day School to meet Major Clark and make their recommendations to him. There are two Baptist missionaries now teaching on the Montana Reserve without remuneration from the Department, at their new Baptist Church on the Montana Reserve, there are from 10 to 15 children attending these classes. May 24, 1948.

Colonel Neary:

Hobema Superintendency,
Baptist Mission and school on the Montana Reserve:

With Mr. T.G. McLeod I went to the m/n reserve on May 18, proceeding part of the way by truck, finishing the journey across flooded areas in a wagon drawn by a team supplied by a white farmer, Mr. Bill Davis of Ponoka.

In the accompanying photo Mr. McLeod is shown seated in the Baptist church-school. At his left are Miss Twila Bartz and Miss Cecilia Priebe.

Miss Bartz is an American college graduate with a teaching certificate from North Dakota. Miss Priebe is not a certificated teacher. They state their denomination as the North American (formerly it was "German") Baptist Church — baptism of adults by complete immersion — with headquarters at Forest Park, Illinois. They have indeed, a closer depot, The Christian Training Institute in Edmonton. The head thereof is the Rev. F.W. Benke, whose address is 10231 98th St., Edmonton.

These young ladies stayed in Edmonton during the winter, and resumed their work on the reserve about April 25.

The building which they use was erected by the denomination primarily as a church. Comfortable living quarters are included at the back. They use water from a creek, boiling it of course. I also saw the place where they began work — a little log cabin owned by an Indian named Standing in-the-road. Living quarters consisted of a trailer which is still standing in the yard.

They have an enrolment of nine pupils with an average attendance of eight. The denominational status of these children is as confused as it is at Louis Bull.

They seem to have obtained sufficient school supplies at church expense. What they want mostly is official recognition.

I had an unexpected conversation with the Rev. Mr. Benke. He took the seat beside me on the train from Nordgaar to Rocky Mountain House (he had been working among the Indians), and, knowing that a school at Bishop's was under consideration, he offered to supply a teacher. I told him that the position might eventually be advertised. At a previous meeting with the Indians they told me that they wanted the school "Protestant". They have a Methodist-United Church tradition.

C.A.F. Clark

Re: Montana Day School

For your information, I beg to report the Montana Day School will be in operation during the coming winter.

The missionary teacher is Mr. Newman, a veteran of the last war, and having seen service in Italy and elsewhere. He and his wife and two children are accommodating themselves in the rear of the church and are building an addition before winter. I have met them, and find them to be most suitable.

At the dedication of the Church, on October 10th, the children who have been in attendance at the school for the past year or two, gave an impressive demonstration of what they have been taught. Children ten and twelve years old spoke in perfect English. A year ago, some of these children could not speak a word of English, like their parents, and usually presented a fairly primitive appearance.

As the presence of this school involves such matters as payment of Family Allowances and general administration, I would be glad of your comments. I am sure it would be very difficult for the Department to get teachers to labor and live among the Indians as these people do. I would suggest that some aid be given to the school, say in the form of scribblers and readers. I am sure that they will be welcome and well used.

(sgd.) H. N. Woodsworth,

Re: Baptist Mission and School - Montana Reserve, Hobbema Indian Agency

With reference to your 112-2-1 (E) of the 27th December 1948, addressed to the Reverend George Dorey, D.D., Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, I have read the copy sent to this office, and I am sure it is a step toward solving some of our administration problems regarding the existence of the school at this Agency. 1. Am I authorized to pay Family Allowances for the children attending this school, according to the Family Allowances Act?

2. Should I have the teacher keep a day school record of attendance to fall in line with this?

3. Will this school be entitled to school supplies such as readers, scribblers, et cetera?

4. Should I require regular medical inspection of the school?

5. Should I have inspection of the school by the School Inspector?

6. Should I send in my inspection report, as I do with the Residential school?

7. Should I have the children attending this school authorized by the Department?

8. Being a day school, the children require a hot noon lunch which they do not bring. At present the Missionary is supplying this.

Attached please find copies of a document handed to me by a group of the Montana Indians, about a month ago which has some bearing on this school. This church school has the support of the majority of the Montana Band, but in my opinion the distance some children have to go is too great.

Re: Baptist Mission Day School
Montana Reserve, Hobbema Indian Agency

With reference to your 112-2-1 (E) of 10th January, 1949, I beg to submit a list of those at present enrolled at the Baptist Mission school, Montana Reserve. There are ten in regular attendance and a potential ten more who have applied to go. Of these ten, the majority are going to the Edmonton Indian Residential School and some to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

Before three interpreters, the Resident Nurse, the Farm Instructor and myself, nearly all the Montana Indians claim to adhere to the teaching and doctrines of the Baptist church.

Mr. R. Neuman has a grade IX standing, plus three years education at a Baptist College in Edmonton, which I am informed, has a good standing in Educational circles. He is a veteran of six years service with the army and was in the First Division serving in Italy. He seems to be as well qualified as any teacher on the Hobbema Indian Agency. It is hoped that all teachers, regardless of religious denomination, be at least of normal standing in the near future.

Good work is being done by Mr. Neuman and wife since their arrival. They have organized sewing clubs among the Indian women, feed their pupils a noon meal, plan to plant a school garden this spring, and in general are carrying out a program of education, which as a whole is showing results, and such that no other church organization has done to date, due to the fact that they are in close contact with the Indians as family units.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

With reference to your 94-112 (T-3) of March 10, and to your comments regarding the present policy of allowing a child to withdraw his savings as soon as he is discharged from School. I readily concur with your suggestion that the savings be kept until the individual attains the age of twenty-one years or marries, as a general policy. I am continually amazed however, at specific cases of young people of seventeen or over who have exhibited mature judgement in the spending of their savings. There is the case of Marcella Lightning who applied all her savings this year to buying a sewing machine and even went to work at a white farmers in order to make up the difference. At present, I have a girl (Marie Wildcat) recently discharged from the Ermineskin School, who has decided not to withdraw her savings until she can get $60.00 or more to enable her to purchase a sewing machine. She is working for various white people to try to attain this end. This girl is also needed at home to aid her widowed mother support a large family. At the conference of Superintendents in Calgary last April, this matter was discussed. At that time, it was pointed out and to which I agree, that the critical period of an Indian life is from the time he leaves school until he gets his feet. He or she is released from discipline into a world of low standards and he must adjust to cope with this situation, without further aid or guidance.

I am continually appalled by the lack of opportunities for the Indians on this Agency. They live in the centre of one of Canada's wealthiest areas and near enlightened centres, yet over a hundred and possibly one hundred and fifty children will never be able to attend school. As you are aware, no school has been built on this Agency since 1890. I see children of people whom I have known since birth sinking gradually into poverty and ignorance as a result. The children who can not find facilities in school are getting married, legally or otherwise, at the ages of 14 years to 18 years. They provide a great problem and I suggest that any arrangement regarding saving this group should be kept in mind. I would appreciate receiving specific instructions as outlined by you and in the meantime, will discourage any further withdrawals. In the case of Barney Montour, I will inform him and his parents that he will have to keep his savings until he marries or attains the age of 21 years. For your information, he is helping his father on a successful farm.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

Extract from letter of March 19, 1949, from Superintendent Woodsworth, Hobbema Alberta. Original on File 94-112.

"I am continually appalled by the lack of opportunities for the Indians on this Agency. They live in the centre of one of Canada's wealthiest areas and near enlightened centres, yet over a hundred and possibly one hundred and fifty children will never be able to attend school. As you are aware, no school has been built on this Agency since 1890. I see children of people whom I have known since birth sinking gradually into poverty and ignorance as a result. The children who can not find facilities in school are getting married, legally or otherwise, at the ages of 14 years and 13 years. They provide a great problem and I suggest that any arrangement regarding saving this group should be kept in mind."

The situation is further examined on the Ermineskin and Louis Bull files.

DATE: 7 June 1949
With Mr. Supt. Woodsworth I visited this school on the morning of Friday, June 10.

There were nine pupils present. The register showed that these were the most dependable of those enrolled.

The room, which is primarily a church, is a model of neatness and cleanliness.

The walls are attractively decorated with pictures, posters and examples of the pupils' work.

There is a commendable emphasis on health habits and personal grooming. The children seem to be developing a self-propelled desire to acquire civilization.

Very good progress has been made in reading by the younger pupils, and the older pupils appear to evince greater interest in other school subjects. Someone, either Mr. Newman or his predecessor, seems to have given momentum to the mental life of these children.

The pupils have planted an extensive garden, divided into plots which will be judged for prizes toward the end of this month. The work is integrated with classroom activities.

This is not an authorized Indian School, but it might be possible for the Department to assist further in the education of these children by donating any of the following:

(a) Some desks
(b) about eight feet of blackboard (photos will follow showing the meagre writing surfaces now available)
(c) a drinking-water container.

Some parents will have to be further instructed regarding truancy, family allowances, and church-affiliation regulations. For example, the mother of two children who left Brimneskin School to attend here does not receive allowances for them on the ground that, for the remainder of this school year, they are considered truants; and yet at recent treaty-payment she again declared herself
an adherent of the Roman Catholic Church.

I have requested the Superintendent to supply us with the form for "Potential School Enrolment" completed for each denomination according to the stand taken by parents at the latest treaty-payment.

C.A.F. Clark

Re: Montana Baptiste Mission Day School

I beg to report that I have visited the Montana Baptiste Mission Day School on the Montana Reserve. I find that this school which started from nothing is progressing in a manner favorable to the welfare of the Indians.

There are sixteen pupils in attendance compared with nine of last year. Some of these pupils belong to the Samson Band which I presume is in order.

The teacher is very appreciative of the aid supplied by the Department in the way of the cups, blackboard, water cooler, books and desks. They were badly needed and with the increase in pupils are a necessity. A noon meal is supplied by the school, the wife of Mr. Neuman performing this function. I suggest that this is a large endeavor.

Recently we received authority to purchase as per departmental list certain janitor supplies and sanitary necessities amounting to a total of $90.20. Mr. Battle, Field Agent from Mr. G. H. Gooderham's office, during a recent visit suggest that quotations might be secured for the Montana Day School at an early date. This school was placed in our 1950-51 estimates. If all plans were developed before April 1st, 1950 and tenders accepted, an early start on the school might be made. This would be of double use, by first enabling the school to be completed in good weather by September 1st, 1950, and secondly, employing Indian labor in this year of crop failure and thereby relieving the financial stress of the Indians.

Our experience in the construction of the Louis Bull Day School has brought out a very important feature lacking in Plan 888; that is basement construction. I have been informed by competent individuals that a full sized basement could have been constructed at less cost than the present foundation. I am also of that opinion.

The construction of a full sized basement would have solved such things as storage space, heating problems, recreation and workshop facilities. The Hobbema Day School is a model of efficiency in this line, having a full basement and furnace.

I am pointing out this feature so that if possible, consideration may be given to amending plan 888 when used on the Montana Reserve. Otherwise, we are well pleased with the school.

Re: Proposed Montana Day School Site, Location and Preparation

I beg to inform you that it will be necessary in preparation for locating the site of the proposed Montana Day School to:

1. Clear approximately 2 acres of brush for school site.

2. Cut a line through the brush on the proposed site of the school comprising approximately 4 acres.

The proposed site of the new school will be approximately one half mile north of the Baptist church which is located in the south-east corner of Section 29. This should place the school almost in the centre of the Montana Reserve, west of the proposed north and south road through the Montana Reserve. There is an iron survey peg near the Baptist church which we will use as a basis of locating the school.

In order to ensure accurate location, the cutting out of the road allowance as a line, is important.

I consider $15.00 per acre to be a fair price for brushing and burning. The total cost, should therefore be $90.00.

If authority was given for us to proceed at an early date, with this necessary preliminary work, I am sure it would have a twofold purpose of completing the essential work and giving badly needed employment to some Indians.

Re: Montana Bay School

I beg to inform you that the Ponoka School Division has a splendid one-room school east of the town, known as the Shultz school. It is about five years old, but has been used only three years. It is 20 x 40 in size, with a cloak room and library. It is finished with insul-brick and inside with tin-tex (unpainted).

It has a basement under it at present, and a furnace.

The school division want $4,000.00 for this building as it stands, without the furnace. They estimate the cost of moving the building to the Montana Reserve would be about $700.00. If this building were constructed at present prices, it would cost at least $8,000.00 minus basement. Mr. Ross, the school inspector of the Ponoka School Division, highly recommends the building for classroom purposes.

The Ponoka School Division has another school west of Hobbema, known as the Poplar Forest school, for which they want $2,500.00, as it stands. It is not as new as the Shultz school and does not compare with it generally. However, it is worth the money and would provide an adequate classroom space.

I would recommend that the Shultz school be acquired and placed on the Montana Reserve, with a basement installation. This very good buy is due to the consolidation of school units in the Ponoka School Division. Possibly Major C.A.F. Clark could investigate further this opportunity. The Poplar Forest school might be acquired also, if the price is reasonable, as an additional unit. This should also be investigated by Major Clark. The money saved and the fact of getting a school ready for September should justify consideration of these purchases. With the money saved, possibly more units could be opened at Hobbema, which are urgently needed.

Montana Indian Day School:

With Mr. Sup't. Wordsworth and Mr. Far Supervisor Sklad I again examined proposed sites for this school. The most suitable site is still the one agreed upon with the late Rev. F.W. Benke.

This site is at the N.E. corner of the N.E. quarter of Section 20. This will place it near the junction of two road allowances.

The land for playground slopes gently toward the south, allowing for drainage. Very little clearing will be required.

The mission will be on the opposite side of the east-west road allowance. There is good water there, which augurs well for a good well at the school. Authority and an accountable advance to explore for water is recommended.

Mr. Wordsworth and I were shown a good school which the Ponoka district wants to sell. It is shown in the accompanying photos. This school could be moved on to the site during the vacation, and be ready to operate at the first of September. Construction of a new school at this point would be a protracted operation. In the present, we could omit a teacherage, as the candidate for the position (Miss Felicity Stroschen, whom I have interviewed) would board at the mission.

Mr. Sklad is preparing a plan of the site. The school which is offered for sale should be oriented with the main windows facing easterly.

1. Pursuant to instructions received from Mr. G.H. Goodhart, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies the above work was undertaken on May 25th and completed on June 5th. In the a.m. of the 25th, accompanied by Asst. Agent Moreauville, the proposed site was visited and examined and in the p.m. the work commenced. A plan of Township 43, Rge. 24, West of the 4th Meridian was secured from the Provincial Technical branch and this showed that some thirty-five years ago a line had been established from a point 24 chains north of the N.E. corner of Sec. 6, due north on a bearing of 270°.01 to the former Methodist Mission Reserve on the Battle River. Assisted by two Indian Arrows, I reopened this line and the remains were found. These were barely discernible and the stakes are gone. This line was opened to the N.E. corner of Sec. 20 and at this point stellar observations were made to determine the true meridian. The magnetic declination here was found to be N 23°.30E. The line was then continued 4000 chains to the S.E. quarter of Sec. 29 and the N.E. corner of the ¼-section established. A line was then opened due west 4 chains, 46.9 links and a stake set. At this point a long rectangular field lying north and south was encountered and this field was crossed on a due west bearing and a second stake set 5 chains west of Stake 1. At Stake 2 the line was run due south 8 chains and stake 3 set and the line then was turned due north. This provided the boundaries of a proposed school site containing 4 acres.

2. On the 31st the land occupied by the school in the Hobbs Settlement and the land adjoining to the south (2 lots) were measured and the boundaries checked. The total content was found to be 29.93 sq. chains. The true boundaries of Lots 7 and 8 were located by the use of the transit.

3. On the 1st, Maj. C.A.F. Clarke of the Welfare Division stated he wished to go to Hobbs and whilst there he examined the proposed site. He decided the school might be located to more advantage near the Baptist Church. A site was then laid out for the school grounds and the building site staked out. Information with regard to this is contained in the attached plan. The corners of the school site are located on the ground and marked by 2x2 wooden stakes. The building site in the grounds has also been staked at the four corners. It will be seen that no levels were taken as this additional work did not seem to be necessary. The building site is practically level. The church building was determined as to location with respect to both road allowances and the school building site aligned to the church. All measurements were chained and checked by stadia.

4. Instruments employed in this work were secured from the University of Alberta Engineering Dept. and the transit was checked in the laboratory and again in the field to assure it being in adjustment. On the the Indian arrows, Alex Mackay, assisted throughout the entire work and is familiar with all locations shown on the attached plan. It will be noted that the content of the school site chosen by Maj. Clarke is 2.40 Ac. He considered this to be sufficient size for this school.

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

Well-drilling at Montana

I telephoned Mr. Woodsworth regarding his telegram of July 7. He explains that in addition to the casing already purchased the drillers recommend the purchase of 280 feet of 2" casing at $1.25 a foot. This casing will be placed inside the present 3" casing so that they can seal off the water presently seeping into the hole as it is not good water. They will then drill down perhaps another 100 feet hoping to find water deep down i.e. around 400 feet. Mr. Superintendent Woodsworth says that the only good wells in this area are deep wells. In fact, the only really good well we have is at the Hobema Day School. Even Ermineskin Residential School has not a first class well. At Louis Bull we had to go down almost 500 feet.

The drillers recommend that we stay with the present hole as almost exactly the same performance might have to be followed elsewhere.

As this additional action is likely to double the original estimate and authorized expenditure I told Mr. Woodsworth that we must first seek Ministerial approval. He has agreed to call in the driller and with his help compose a night letter describing the situation and giving a new estimate with his recommendation.

Re: Montana Day School Well

Attached find a copy of a telegram sent to Col. Neary indicating the failure to find satisfactory water supply on the proposed site of the Montana Day School.

The well drillers at 265 feet found a mud formation which kept dissolving in the water found at this depth. No amount of pumping corrected the supply. The water was not of great flow but might have provided sufficient for the school. They intended to go down to 300 feet if they had been able to clear the water from the mud.

In order to cut off this formation considerable more casing would have to be put down and then the well drilled past 300 feet. No assurance would be forthcoming that adequate water would be found. It would be very costly to do this.

In the case of the Louis Bull Day School well no mud formation was encountered and drilling past 300 feet did not necessitate placing in more casing.

The well drillers do not like the look of the situation generally and have left the site to drill a band well on the Samson Reserve pending the decision of the authorities in the matter.

Surface water in limited quantities is available. I could not advise you whether or not sufficient of this type of water could be found to supply the school needs. The Montana Baptist Church has a surface well which supplies small amounts of water. It had to be deepened last year as it dried up but at date of writing has sufficient water to provide the needs of the Missionaries and the children attending the school.

Re: Montana (Hobbema #3) Indian Day School,

In a memorandum dated May 25, 1950, we recommended an expenditure of approximately $420.00 to drill a well at the above school. This recommendation was approved by the Minister.

We are now advised by Indian Superintendent Woodsworth that a depth of two hundred and sixty-five feet has been drilled but water has not been obtained.

The well-driller has recommended to our Superintendent that the drilling should be continued to a depth of five hundred feet and the driller believes that if this is done there is a reasonable likelihood of securing water.

The additional expenditure for labour and casing etc., will be $536.80. If water is not struck, the bulk of the casing etc., can be recovered and used again.
