Mr. G. H. Gooderham,

Re: Montana Day School Well.

Attached find a copy of a telegram sent to Col. Neary indicating the failure to find satisfactory water supply on the proposed site of the Montana Day School.

The well drillers at 265 feet found a mud formation which kept dissolving in the water found at this depth. No amount of pumping corrected the supply. The water was not of great flow but might have provided sufficient for the school. They intended to go down to 300 feet if they had been able to clear the water from the mud.

In order to cut off this formation considerable more casing would have to be put down and then the well drilled past 300 feet. No assurance would be forthcoming that adequate water would be found. It would be very costly to do this.

In the case of the Louis Bull Day School well no mud formation was encountered and drilling past 300 feet did not necessitate placing in more casing.

The well drillers do not like the look of the situation generally and have left the site to drill a hand well on the Samson reserve pending decision of the authorities in the matter.

Surface water in limited quantities is available. I could not advise you whether or not sufficient of this type of water could be found to supply the school needs. The Montana Baptist Church has a surface well which supplies small amounts of water. It had to be deepened last year as it dried up but at date of writing has sufficient water to provide the needs of the Missionaries and the children attending the school.

Montana (Hobbema No. 3) Indian Day School

In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, we advertised for tenders for the erection of the Montana Indian Day School on the Hobbema Indian Reserve.

One tender only was received and that from the Yukon Construction Company Limited, 9907-103rd Street, Edmonton, Alberta. It was in the amount of $32,797.00, which is considered a very high bid for the erection of a one-room day school and teacherage.

I could not recommend the acceptance of this tender.

Fortunately, the Ponoka School Division No. 34 has been carrying out a programme of consolidation and has a one-room school which we can purchase. Please find attached photographs showing the school which is for sale and also a letter from the School Division advising that the price will be $4,000.00. Our officials have examined this building and feel that this is a fair and reasonable price.

It is expected that the total cost, including installation of basement and removal of building to the new site, will be about $6,200.00. We have obtained tenders for the installation of the basement required and also for the moving of the school.

These are being sent to you under separate cover.

I would recommend the purchase of this building.

Recommended

Re: Montana Indian Day School.
Your file 725-5.

Your wire of the 23rd was received as Mr. Allan and I were leaving for Hobbema and I had an opportunity on the 24th to visit this site. Instructions were given to have Mr. Dawson, the Surveyor who was at the Agency to establish the roads to the east and north. This was done and Mr. Gee was advised that his tender was accepted, as was Mr. Frizzell's removing the school. On the 6th I was again at Hobbema when the actual site of the building was staked out to leave the well on the north west corner. Mr. Gee moved on to the location that day and was instructed to cement a pit on the well site connecting with the basement of the school. I did not have an opportunity to inspect the Poplar Forest and Manito Schools which you refer to in your letter of August 31st file 721-5 but Mr. Battle had inspected them and advised that the Manito was in his opinion the better building to be converted into a teacherage. I instructed Mr. Woodsworth to contact the Secretary of the Ponoka School Board and ascertain what was the lowest that the Board would accept and at the same time to get a bid from Mr. Frizzell for moving the school and alternate bids from Mr. Gee, as quickly as possible and advise this office.

1. Eighteen hundred dollars is the price set for the school by the Board and no reduction can be anticipated.
2. Mr. Frizzell will move the school a distance of about (20 miles), place it on a foundation with new wooden plates for $648.90.
3. To date no bid for the basement has been received from Mr. Gee but it is my estimate that he will ask for at least $1,000.00 to erect retaining walls and a half basement; $1,400.00 to erect a full basement.

From the foregoing it must be assumed that the total cost of putting this building on the site to be in the neighbor-
hood of $4,000.00. The alterations to make it suitable for a teacherage should include the dropping of the ceiling + 2 partitions & possible insulation and small repairs and a furnace, which is estimated to cost $2,000.00. The total cost should not exceed $6,000.00.

I recommend the purchase of the building and a full basement unless there is a considerable difference between a full and half basement, which is not anticipated as a half basement is not economical since retaining walls must be erected.

A good teacherage could not be erected for less and certainly it would not be as big as this building. As it is badly needed, I hope that authority can be given immediately to purchase and accept the tenders so that Mr. Gee might remain on the site and do the teacherage basement on completion of the school basement.

Under separate cover, I am writing you regarding the use of the Baptist Church and teacherage until such time as the school and teacherage are ready for occupancy.

As quickly as possible, kindly wire.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Re: Montana Day Schools,

Mr. Newman, the Baptist Missionary on the Montana Reserve, has been most co-operative in the operation of a school among these Indians. As the Baptist Church is not receiving any grant, he has asked that a rental be paid for the use of the church and for the room supplied to the teacher until the Indian school and teacherage are ready to occupy. This is a very fair request and it is recommended that a rental of $25.00 per month be paid for the use of the church and $15.00 per month for room rent.

The Missionary quarters are very crowded as Mr. Newman has a large family and it is our hope that the teacherage will be ready for use before the end of the current year.

Toronto, 3rd Jan., 1864.

To Indian School at Saddle Lake.

Sir,

A third time an information reached me that the Indian day school at Saddle Lake, N.W.T. had been closed by the discretion of the Agent or Inspector, on the ground, I believe, of the very small attendance. It appears that subsequently the teacher there, Mr. Leonard, re-opened the school on his own authority, but at the request of various parties in the neighborhood, and has been carrying it on since then. He expressed the opinion that the small attendance was due largely to the location of the school, which was not convenient for many of the Protestant Indians on the Reserve, and recommended that another site be selected, if possible, some distance away. Since then, as I am informed, the Reserve was visited by the Rev. John McDougall, Superintendent of Northern Indian Missions in the North-West, and after consultation the Indians agreed to set aside a certain portion of land for the use of the Mission, so long as the Missionary Society continued its work at that point. I presume that this matter has been brought to the notice of the Department before this time, but I write now respecting two points: First, That I think it very desirable that a school should be maintained at Saddle Lake, and the customary grant be made by the Department for the purpose; and Second, That it is very desirable that when any changes are proposed respecting schools
that have been carried on under the auspices of the Methodist Church, that I should be informed at the time of what is proposed. I find that in some cases important changes are made by the Indian Agent, either independently or in consultation with the missionary, so by instruction of the Superintendent, or when I have no information, and some times even without the slightest advice I know what has been done—without even that the information reached me in time to instruct you.

It is in the wish of the Superintendent that, in regard to matters in his jurisdiction, that he should communicate with the Indian Commissioner. As trustees we will willingly do our best to do very desirable work in this way we should be happy to receive any advice or any proposed changes.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. Sutherland

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to Mr Leonard's letter regarding the closing of the Saddle Lake school, I beg to say that this school was closed on the 30th June 1903 by direction of the Indian Commissioner with the consent of the Department, on account of the very unsatisfactory attendance of Indian pupils, the average for that year having fallen to 4, and for the last quarter it did not reach two. Rev. Dr Sutherland, General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, wrote the Department regarding the closing of this school and the Indian Commissioner was asked for a report on the subject. He expressed the opinion that it did not seem worth while to keep the school open and enclosed a copy of a letter from Agent Mann regarding this school, from which it appears that there were only 11 children of school age belonging to the Methodists residing on the Saddle Lake portion of the reserve. Only 6 of these children live within a reasonable distance of the school and one of them (a boy) was of unsound mind. A sketch accompanied Mr Mann's letter showing the location of the Indians houses around Saddle Lake and the situation of the schoolhouse, which proved his contention that most of the Indians live too far from the school for their children to attend, and it would not seem possible to place the schoolhouse in a more favorable situation.
The Agent in his report did say that the teacher, Mr Leonard was not well liked by the Indians caused chiefly through his transactions with them, over which there were differences and that two families had refused to send their children to school on this account. The Indians claimed that the teacher's disposition towards them was not a pleasant one, with other remarks which reflected no credit upon him.

The Agent was of the opinion that the teacher had shown a disposition to encourage the children to attend school, maintaining that his part of the work was merely to be on hand and teach the children when they came to school. The Agent concluded by stating that the teacher's over-bearing manner had not a good effect upon the Indians.

In March 1904 Dr Sutherland was advised that as a result of the enquiries made, the Department considered that it would not be justified in again reopening this school, as there were only a very limited number of children of school age on the reserve who could possibly be regular attendants, owing to the distance they would have to go, and that even if the school were removed to a new site, matters would not be improved.

After the school was closed in 1903, Mr Leonard re-opened it on his own authority at the request of various parties in the neighborhood, and in Jan. 1904 when the Department was advised of his action by Dr Sutherland, he was carrying it on, and may still be continuing it.

In June 1904 the Asst. Commissioner forwarded a copy of a letter addressed by him to Rev. John McDougall, Supt. of Indian missions in the N.W.T., who
had visited the reserve after the closing of the school. A copy of Mr McKenna's letter to Mr McDougall is turned out on file herewith, from which you will see that he suggested to McDougall the naming of a substitute for Mr Leonard, when the school would be kept open until it could be learned from the results under the new man, whether they would warrant its continuance. Up to the present time the school has not been officially re-opened and the Department is not aware of what steps have been taken to have this done.

It is no doubt a hardship to the officials not to have a school for their children, but the Department is not supposed to conduct one for this purpose. The small attendance was sufficient cause for the closing of the school, and the Agent's report as to the unpopularity of the teacher would justify the Department in asking for a change if the school were to be re-opened.

Dear Sir:

It is a very rare thing for me to write a letter of complaint. I am under obligation to do so now however. It is re the attitude of the Indian Agent to our school work here. We have put up with almost everything up to the present calculated to discourage us in our school work. We have come to the place now where silence ceases to be golden.

Let me go back in my story so as to give you an idea of the situation. When Mrs Seller took charge of the school two years ago it was soon quite noticeable that Mr. Batty did not take any interest in the work of the school. When fall came on with some persuasion we succeeded in getting the school in good shape for the winter. That was the fall of 1907. So far there had been nothing to complain of. The winter of that year saw a great deal of hardship in procuring wood and getting it cut up for the school. I provided a good deal of the wood myself and day after day went to the school and cut up wood necessary for the day. I did not do this, however, without approaching Mr. Batty over and over again about it. I got tired of that. So I thought I would try a new plan and made an arrangement with the Agent that I should hire the Indians to bring wood to the school and cut it and send the bill to him. This I have done ever since and the wood problem has been fairly well solved, giving me, however, work which belongs to the Agent.

Matters moved along fairly well then until the fall of '08, when time came to have the old log school fitted up for the winter. I requested Mr. Batty to get the school mudded for us. He gave me no assurance that he would do it and at last
put me off by saying "That is not my business; that is the work of the Farm Instructor; go to him about it." The Farm Instructor did not think it was his duty, and so the old school went unmudded. When the cold winter came we found that it would be impossible to hold school there, and rather than close school altogether we opened our home for a school and took the children into our own home. You can imagine how inconvenient that was for us.

Then we fitted up the old kitchen into a school. Happily I had had it mudded before the winter set in. That is where school is being held yet.

Now I took all this which I have related in the best of good nature. I did not complain or say an impatient word even to Mr. Batty. I am writing this letter to you now because I have heard from the office here that Mr. Batty is using his influence with the Department to have the school closed altogether; and why, I do not know.

Of course there is a very small attendance. I have it to say though, and without the least reservation, that if the Indian Agent here took the least interest at all in the school it would be an easy matter to get a larger attendance. Possibly you know that it is the duty of the Agent to visit the Indian schools once each month and send in to the Department a very detailed report of his visit to the school. Well you will be amazed to learn, and the Dept. through you, I trust, that he did not pay even one official visit to the school since Mrs Seller took charge of it two years ago. Notwithstanding this he has sent in a full report of a visit each month.

You have no doubt read that pamphlet entitled, "Regulations relating to the education of Indian children," printed in 1908, containing the recent Act of our Government re this matter. We believe this to be a valuable aid to us in our work if - if - we had an Agent who would show the least inclination to do the part
assigned him in this pamphlet. Before I had a copy in my possession I went to him and asked him if he had not power given him to see that Indian children attended school. He said he knew of nothing of any such regulation as I mentioned. I had at the same time positive proof that he had read them and discussed them with others. I told him that I had read the Act, and then he modified what he had said by stating that the Department did not desire him to put that into force.

Now we have a Methodist family within the two mile area who will not send their children to school. The father has turned out to be a sort of medicine man, and does not want to send his children to school. This is the family I had in mind when, during the last few months, I have gone to the Agent to secure his assistance. I do not think that any drastic measures would have to be used in getting these children to school if the Agent would only take up the matter with them and show them what the law requires.

We look upon our school work here as the most hopeful side of our work if only we could secure the attendance of our Indian children. So far as I can see there is no reason why we should not have an average of 18 or 20 children attending school. My own mind in the matter is, if the Indian Department would only build a good school in a more central part of the protestant portion of this Reserve, and if teams were sent round every morning to the doors of the homes where children are, and these teams took the children back again in the evening, that at least 20 children could be at school every day. A compulsory Act under such a system would then be workable and might be put into force without much friction. Of course it would cost a little more, but would it not be wise to spend a little more and get some results? The inefficiency of our school work at this point has cost us more heartache than any other thing. What will become of our work here
if this problem is not more efficiently solved? I know of several children whom we will lose if we do not do something right away.

I am writing this letter to you, dear Doctor Sutherland, to ask you to take up this matter with the Department and see that this school is not closed here. This letter is not written in a few minutes of "the blues", (that's a trouble I know very little about) It is written after a great deal of deliberation. I want your counsel in this matter, also your influence to see that the Agent is made do his duty in regard to school work. I have not written any complaints to the I.D. This is the first I have written or said outside about the matter.

Trusting that I may hear from you soon re this matter of most vital importance to our work here.

I am,

Yours fraternaly,
(Signed) J. A. Seller.

Dear Sir:

Re Saddle Lake Indian School.

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th inst., #117060, referring to the Indian School at Saddle Lake. It is conceded that the old school building is unfit for use and not worth repairing, but the Department thinks it would not be justified in going to the expense of erecting a new building on the site we have suggested, or, indeed, anywhere on the reserve, as it is doubtful where the Indians will permanently locate.

There are features of this question which I find it difficult to understand. In interviews and correspondence with the Department we have been given distinctly to understand that the Minister was entirely in favor of improving the character and work of Indian Day Schools, rather than provide additional Boarding Schools or Institutes. Although we were not very sanguine as to the results of Day School work, yet we were willing to support the Minister in this policy and give it a fair trial. With a view to bringing about a more satisfactory state of things on the Saddle Lake Reserve, we stationed a very able and conscientious man at that point, whose wife is thoroughly competent as a teacher, provided another could not be secured. To further encourage the Indians, we aided them in the erection of a new Church on a new site much more convenient than the old one. We also have erected, this Summer, a dwelling for the Missionary, and are doing everything to show the Indians that this is a permanent location, and we wish to encourage them in settling on the most convenient part of the reserve. The school we considered a necessity in carrying out the general plan,
although we would have preferred a Boarding School for the Saddle Lake, White Fish Lake, and Good Fish Lake Indians, had such a plan been favored by the Minister. To have the plan of the Day School blocked at this stage is not only disappointing in itself, but has another very serious aspect, namely, that it is the very thing which encourages, or almost compels, Indians, if they desire their children to be educated at all, to send them to some of the existing Boarding Schools, and as no Protestant Boarding School is within reach the alternative is very plain. Like Indians everywhere, those at Saddle Lake may not be much interested in education for their children, but, with proper facilities provided, and the influence of a man like the Rev. Mr. Seller, I feel convinced that in course of time, and not very long time at that, the greater part of the children would be gathered into the school, and if some expense would be incurred in bringing in those who live at a distance it would be a very wise expenditure in view of possible results. Knowing that a new dwelling for the Indian Agent had been erected, we were confirmed in the impression that Saddle Lake was to be continued as a centre, and it seems to me that Saddle Lake is one of the very places where the new policy of the Department respecting Day Schools should have a fair trial.

Your obedient servant,

General Secretary.

I was at the Saddle Lake Agency during the greater portion of the month of September and I intended to take a visit to the day school before leaving but was called away hastily by the Superintendent General and failed to visit this institution.

1. From what I gathered, however, I did not mind much. The attendance at best was 4 or 5 and they only attended now and again. Moreover, the Rev. Mr. Macdonald of the Onion Lake boarding school had visited the reserve and arranged for the transfer of several of the pupils to the Onion Lake school.

2. While at the agency I made up a map of the reserve and on it showed the location of the homes of the children of school age. From it I concluded that it would be no easy task to get a regular attendance at a day school within this reserve - locate it at any point.

3. This school is under the auspices of the Methodist Church and with Mrs. Ayer as the teacher. I do not think Mrs. Ayer holds any standard of a teachers certificate.

4. The old school building was abandoned some months before and Mrs. Ayer was occupying the old mission house and teaching, when any children to teach, in one of the unoccupied rooms of this mission house. It is about

All the children on this list are Treaty Indian children and Protestants. Four of them, two of Simon Wasatanow's and two of Daniel Makokis' have gone to Onion Lake since I sent you my previous reckoning. This means that eighteen Treaty Indian children are still with us.

When I wrote you that letter containing the reckoning of the number of school children here I included the children of a family not entitled to Treaty because they have taken up a homestead just outside of the Reserve. I hardly understand why such children should be discriminated against. Ought they not rather to be favored because of the very fact that the father has given up Treaty rights and stepped out for himself? There are three children in this family and they reside nearer than a number of Treaty children. I included them in my former estimate of the children it would be possible to convey to and from school and thus educate them. Then there are two or three other not Protestant children from whose parents I have secured promises of attendance at school if a team conveyed them to and from the school. In each case these children are several miles from school.

The point of importance before us in this regard however, is this: That eighteen Treaty Indian children are still with us, that this is correct and that the report of the Inspector is not correct. When the report of the Inspector was sent in, moreover, the two children of Daniel Makokis had not gone to Onion Lake. His report should have been
twenty (20) and not thirteen (13).

I have great respect for Inspector Markle and a high opinion of his judgment but he receives his information from the agent here and that is why it is incorrect. I am quite sure that the Inspector is not in any way prejudiced against our interests and that he has no idea that his report is an incorrect one.

I am asked for suggestions re the problem here. In reply I may say that I do not think I can do anything more than I have already done to increase the attendance at school. Of the eighteen children here not more than ten are within two miles and a half from the school.

One of the things that makes it hard to conduct day-school is the lack of respect on the part of the Indians for our day school. I do not wonder at this.

The school house that has to be abandoned on December of 1908 was a disgrace to the place, and now that the school meets in a dingy, dark, old kitchen of a ready-to-be-abandoned mission-house with no spot in which to hang a map, two small windows which some days let in scarcely enough light to enable the children to read and desks so huddled around as to make it difficult to draw up a class into line, the situation is scarcely improved.

Now when you add to this the facts I disclosed in my last letter re this matter, as to the way the Agent at this point has treated this school (I ask) can you wonder that the Indian has lost respect for our
day school? How can a teacher, missionary or anyone else, be expected to do much to improve the situation under present conditions?

I have only one suggestion to offer and it is this: That the problem of the education of children here and at Goodfish and Whitefish Lakes can be best solved by erecting a boarding school. The day school will never begin to work out this problem. This is seen plainly when you consider the following facts:

1. Only ten out of the eighteen children mentioned above are near enough to attend school and four of them are between two miles and two and a half miles away.

2. There ten children come from four families. Now if two of these families happen to be away for two or three months of the school year (as is often the case), not these two families are inevitably those with the largest number of scholars (namely Sam Steinhauser and James Cardinal), there are very few children left to attend school.

3. The fact that these eighteen children are scattered over an area whose radius, taking the old mission house as a centre, is eight miles.

If these children were conveyed to and from school, the problem might be partially solved but probably this method would be too expensive for returns realized. This method would not meet the difficulty outlined above in 2.

The erection of a Boarding School here or between here and Goodfish Lake, sufficient to accommodate all the children on Brother Steinhauser's Mission and on my own, will be the first move in my humble opinion, toward the most successful working out of the situation in this work which we represent. I may emphatically state that I have no personal interest in recommending a
Boarding School here for I have no ambition in this direction and am penning these words with only one feeling that of an intense longing for the education of our Indian boys and girls. I feel sure that if the Red Deer Industrial Institute were within fifty miles of this Reserve the children now drifting from us into the Onion Lake School would be attending our own Institution. We would much rather have them attend the school at Onion Lake than have them drift into the R.C. Boarding School but why should not the Methodist Church be training her own Indian boys and girls?

I humbly submit to you the result of my findings as a missionary of two years and a half among the Indians here and trust that my letter is sufficiently plain to be readily understood.

Yours fraternaly,

(Signed) J.A.Seller.

Attendance, etc.

New and proper buildings, transport of pupils to and from the school and, first, I think, Indians to agree to regular attendance, compulsion to be agreed to by Indians, if they fail to carry out such a promise.

Buildings and Premises.

There is the old school building, log walls, not in use for about 7 years and unfit for use. Location not good either. The school now in operation is held in the parlour of the parsonage. Too small and otherwise unsuited. Anyway neither Mr. or Mrs. Sellar disposed to use this room for this purpose much longer. They claim, with reason, upsets their home and home life. Agreed to its use for a period to test Indians as to their true desire for a school.

General Remarks.

If a day school to be maintained on this reserve, I think a new building first required. Building containing a class, dining and kitchen room as well as a vestibule and small store room to hold supplies. Building should be in most central location. Before I would provide such a building, I would ask the interested Indians to sign an agreement promising to send their children between ages of 7 and 12 years to this school. Agreement to include that they agreed to compulsion in event of them failing to meet promise. Then when children attain 12 years of age parents to agree to transfer them to a higher school—say to Red Deer Industrial—if the Department so desired. On such an agreement might be safe for Department to provide a proper new school building, transport and a mid-day meal. Might be necessary, too, to provide house accommodation for a teacher, some one who is capable and willing to give full time to the work. Schools where children go remain home or absent themselves from school for trivial reasons are, in my opinion, largely a waste of funds and energy. Children cannot be expected to advance in a strange language unless they attend school regularly. If schools are an advantage to Indians they should take advantage of them when provided and not "play School".

Sgd. J. A. Markle,

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following with regard to the Saddle Lake day school as it is now operated and express some opinions regarding a new school building and which I understand is under contemplation.

About the end of May last I reported the desires of the Indians, chiefly advanced by the Rev. Mr. Sellar, for a new school. I suggested to the Department that it might be prudent to ask the Indians for some guarantee that they would use the school if it was provided. In a letter received from the Department, dated June 24, No. 117060/1, this suggestion was approved. For the reason that I was not likely to visit that reserve for some months I requested Mr. Agent Hughes to take up the matter with Mr. Sellar and the Indians. I advised being very particular with regard to the Indians understanding the question of compulsion, in event they neglected to send their children to the school if one provided, and to see that the signatures of the Indians were witnessed.

Soon after I arrived at the Agency this month I learned that some sort of a document had gone forward to the Department but no copy was in the office and unable, therefore, to judge as to its merits. I learned at a later date that the Indians strongly objected to the compulsory clause and had only agreed to it when they were told that the Department were not likely to provide a school without. This, in my opinion, is too loose a bargain for they may demand an unreasonable sum for this work. Another question apparently unsettled is the cost of transporting the pupils to and from the school, for I presume it is the intention to provide a mid-day lunch and transport. My impression is that a far more satisfactory building could have been erected of frame than of logs. The Indians probably would have given about 15000' of lumber and if a frame building were erected on a substantial cement concrete foundation I feel sure the after expense would be much less than the annual cost of keeping up a log walled structure. I question whether the lumber could now be secured from the Indians. They would require time to get out logs to be sawn and the winter months is the proper period to do this.

I do not know the policy of either the Department or the Methodist Church on this school question. If it is that this and similar schools are to be nurseries for the Red Deer Industrial School I suspect the Indians do not entertain this view. Their notion is that this and similar
similar schools are intended to supplant the Industrial School. I question whether the Indians do not entertain still wider views. There are Indians on the saddle Lake Reserve who claim allegiance to the Roman Catholic Faith. Still my impression is that these same Indians, or some of them at least, are contemplating sending their children to the proposed new school, if it is provided. In fact I believe if they were allowed to so do some would withdraw children from the Blue Quill's School under the plea that they intended to send them to this new school. In fact it would not surprise me if some renounced their faith to carry this into effect.

If it is the policy of the Department and the Methodist Church to close up the Red Deer School and to operate mid-day lunch schools on this, the Whitefish Samson's and Paul's Reserves I think they may all be fairly successful if started on clear understandings with regard to regular attendance, the compulsion carried out from the start and efficient teachers placed in charge, but not otherwise.

Dear Sir,

It is the prevalent idea that the Indian Day School is a total failure, and this conclusion has been arrived at, not without reason. In comparison with the work done in Industrial and Board schools, the day-schools fail very low. And yet, there is a conviction that the day-school need not be a total failure.

I seem to me that much might be accomplished, if the work were more strictly confined to the teaching of reading, writing and arithmetic, while an extreme effort is made to have the pupils understand what they are reading about, and as far as possible to have them speak the English language. With this conviction in my mind, I have taken hold of the work of this school this year, with the idea of making a test year of it. I want to know for myself just what can be accomplished in one year, by keeping the pupils constantly at work, and requiring them to ask and answer.
questions, during the English language lesson, they are asked to answer first in English then in Cree and English alternately, sentence by sentence, and finally I have them answer me in English only. I do not doubt the very effectiveness, they get a good grasp of the meaning of each lesson story. I have reason to believe, that, as soon as the raising is over, we will have a more regular attendance than has been usual, since this school began. We have found it necessary to keep the children employed every moment of the time from opening in the morning until blowing at dinner; and this, I feel, ought to be of great value for their moral effect. Some have said all education was futile, and that it is the acquisition of English that ought to be chief concern.

Now, I believe we do the best possible work. We must receive much nourishment from many of the pupils here, yet, there seems nothing ideal about any child whatever, wholly dependent on it. We secure food for them. Most of them come to us distances from one to four miles, so that they have to leave immediately, and it is late when they get home again. It is my belief that
These pupils would do much better work and would enjoy their school life infinitely better if a warm meal were provided for them each day at noon. This would necessitate meat of some kind, rice, beans and seasoning. Also the necessary equipment for cooking and serving. The following list I think will include all requirements.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith, a letter received from Mrs. J. A. Seller in connection with the Saddle Lake Day school. She states that it is the prevalent idea that the Indian Day school is a total failure.

Speaking from my own experience, I regret to state that the Day schools here have proved to be a failure.

The mid-day meals given at these schools are an inducement to some of the pupils to attend school for a short time but the novelty of going to school for a hot lunch soon wears off and in my opinion, these meals are a detriment to the parents of the children who are attending school as well as the children themselves, as they are given object lessons in expecting to receive something for nothing, and the indolence and pauperism which is to be found on the reserves, could, I believe, be traced back to some such beginning as this in a good many cases.

As an illustration, I would quote the Whitefish Lake Band No. 125. These people had been receiving rations and assistance in different other forms until some three years ago. Since that time, with the exception of three or four cases which have been supplied, no rations have been issued and in the last three years or so, the Indians there have
have made more progress than they have ever done in twice the time previous to the closing of the ration house, and I believe that this was due to the fact that the Indians were given to understand that they were expected to work for a living and that they were not to expect the issue of rations regularly as they had been formerly.

The same might be said of the Indians of the Saddle Lake reserve. A liberal ration has been allowed these Indians regularly and they had formed habits of loafing around home until they were hungry and then coming to the ration house where they took it for granted, free rations would be issued to them.

Last Spring, the quantity of rations usually issued was cut down and I have not seen any suffering among the Indians to date and in fact, I believe that they have made a better living this year (considering the scarcity of money) than they have done in other years.

In view of what I have learned from my experience with the Day schools and from the foregoing facts, I have come to the conclusion that the sooner the young Indians are taught and given to understand that they must be self-supporting, the sooner we will see an improvement in conditions among the Indians, and in my opinion the children should learn this in the schools, instead of being led to think that they had a right to expect assistance.

Under the circumstances and from what I know of existing conditions, I do not feel that I can make any recommendation in connection with Mrs. Seller's requests.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

SADDLE LAKE DAY SCHOOL:

This school is held in the Methodist Church on Saddle Lake reserve. Mr. D. Rankin is in charge as teacher. He holds a second class professional certificate. There are 20 pupils enrolled. The average attendance for the December quarter being 14.3. Nine pupils were present on the day of my visit, 6 boys and 3 girls. I gave them a brief examination and found them very backward. They do not speak up well and I had difficulty in hearing them. The attendance in January was very poor owing to the severity of the weather. I found the building comfortable and the pupils present looked clean and healthy.

It is very apparent that the parents do not appreciate this school inasmuch as the pupils enrolled live within a radius of three miles and if they were interested, the attendance should be greater than it is. I may say that a number of the pupils have been recruited for the new Boarding school at Edmonton.

Sir:

Through your local Agent, we have been informed that our Saddle Lake Day School is closed for good. When we heard that this was done, every Indian who has a child or lives protected against it. For this reason, they do not wish to part with their child or children when they are just reaching school age, taken away from them to some school situated some distance away. Parental responsibility is taken away from them, which is unnatural.

The school throughout the year has been very satisfactorily carried out its work through the leadership of Mr. Rankin. Children have made good progress in the last quarter, showed an average attendance of 11.2 out of an enrollment of 15.
As a rule attendance usually falls down, because people move away from their homes, but it so happens that the families from which children come have been staying on their homes and working on their land.

Besides we have some supplies, such as wood, and some stationary, which are on hand heavy on the work.

The provision school was opened again.

The danger, I see in such a step is this, some poor protestant Indians are bound their children to this Roman Catholic Boarding School, where they can see them as often as they will and in the end become Catholics.

The sad mistake (allow me to point it out) the Department has made in the closing four Day School, is the idea of forcing the Indians to send their children where they don't think to be while very young.

Yours sincerely,

R. B. Graham

Dear Sir:

It is not often that I trouble you, nor caring to write without sufficient cause, I accordingly hope that you will take into consideration these few lines I take the liberty to send in regard to our school.

More than myself you are aware of what our day schools are, and how unsatisfactory are the results of the same. Our school at Cold Lake, it goes without saying is no exception to the general rule.

With such unsuccessful efforts, and knowing the governments desire to establish and maintain on all the reserves, Boarding Schools, which give entirely different results, I, in my turn, now take the liberty to make a request for such a school to be established here, assuring you that nowhere could such an institution be more usefully maintained than here.

All our Chipewyan desire to see their children well educated, and the children themselves generally like to come to school. What do we see however? Out of 43 or 49 children of school age, 10, 11, and occasionally 12, only, and always the same attend daily. Why do not the others come, because in the first place, they have

Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
too great a distance to go over. As a matter of fact, only six live within something less than a mile from the school, some five or six more live within nearly two miles from it, some few others within 2½ or 3 miles, others within 4 or 5 miles, others again within 6 miles, a good number are 3 or 9 miles away, and at last, few, 14 or 16 miles from the school. The reason of this is that many families who formerly and until recently were settled near my mission, have gradually dispersed, and went to live in proximity to their hay grounds, to avoid the ever increasing amount of hay which they had to transport.

Again, you must be aware that for a number of years the Government has left the Chipewayans to their own resources, giving them none of the help which is given to the other Indians on all the Reserves. Hence, for our people, both those of whom the children live near the school, and the others, periods of penury, of want which force them to take the gun and go to the bush with wife and children not to starve at home. This is a great reason for the frequent lowering of the schools average attendance. For all these reasons, I repeat, that nowhere could the establishment of a boarding school be more desirable than here. I therefore am bold enough to urge you to authorize us to open such a school, the operation of which to begin on the 1st July of next year 1896.

I have told you at the beginning of this, that we had 43 or 49 children of school age. If you could authorize us to take about 40 boarders, the Sisters
which we most probably will have by next year, will possibly be able to take the balance at their own cost, and so all would be in a position to receive the education they are so desirous of obtaining.

sgd. L. Legoff. Ptr. O.M.I.

Honourable Sir,

Application has been made, already several times, for the establishment of a Boarding School amongst the Chipewyans at Cold Lake, Saskatchewan. There are quite a large band of Indians and all Catholics, and a school for their children is so much more desirable that these Indians are still, to a great extent, hunters, and are obliged to take their children with them; so that a day school, always a very poor means of success, anywhere among the Indians, is of no practicability here.

Sir,

Complying with instructions contained in your letter above quoted I have the honor to report as follows:

The Chippewayan band at Cold includes 271 persons, of whom 60 are between the ages of 6 and fifteen inclusive, and 60 are under 6 years. It will thus be seen that the population eligible by age for attendance at school is large, and is likely to be recruited from year to year, according as these pass the age limit, from those who are now under the minimum age.

Of those who are between 6 and 15 years 35 live within the limits of the reserve, and with few exceptions within two miles of a central point at or near the Mission; while 25 live outside the reserve, for the most part on the north side of the Beaver River, (the reserve being on the south), and at distances of from two to five miles from the Mission.

The reserve includes two townships, being 8 miles from east to west and nine miles from south to north; but only the northern and north-eastern portion is occupied by the Indians. Those living on the reserve could, accordingly, be served by a day school; but when the day school was in operation, as it was for several years, the attendance was but poor, although the Indians lived then in nearly the same places as at present.

The agitation for the establishment of a boarding school here has been going on for some years locally, and it has

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
it has been discouraged by the Agent and myself in the interest of a better attendance at the Roman Catholic school at Onion Lake. The Chippewyans, however, send their children only with reluctance, if at all, to the Onion Lake school, where the attendance is otherwise entirely Cree. They recall the fact that a number of the children they have sent there have died, and they claim they have been at times ill-used by their schoolmates, regarding the Crees as a rougher class than themselves.

I never found that their fears as to their children being ill-treated were justified, although it is true in any Indian school that the vex ill treatment of the younger by the older, the weaker by the stronger, would be a matter of daily occurrence if it were not for the vigilance of those in charge. And as for the sickness and death of some of their children, the fault does not belong peculiarly to this or any other school, for it is only too well known that boarding school life is unsuited to the Indians of this generation and distinctly injurious to their health.

However, as regards the case in question, the boarding school at Onion Lake has not served, and is not likely to serve, the needs of the Chippewayan band; and as against the general objection to boarding schools above referred to there are two main considerations in favor of the establishment of a boarding school for this band. In the first place the population is so scattered, on and outside of the reserve, that they cannot in any large measure reap the benefits of a day school; and secondly, now that the hunt is failing, these people are becoming poorer year by year, and in many cases are unable to feed and clothe their children properly. A boarding school would, accordingly, to a greater extent than on most reserves, be a charitable as well as an educational institution.

There is little doubt that in case a boarding school were established on this reserve admission would be sought for nearly all the healthy children of school age in the band.

Yet,
Yet, since under a strict medical examination a large percentage would probably be found ineligible, a school with accommodation for thirty pupils would be sufficient. There is also a small band of Chippewayans at Heart Lake, about sixty miles to the west, who are a branch from this band, and whose children could be accommodated here.

If, however, it is the policy of the Department to restrict the development of the boarding school system, the work of education could be accomplished otherwise. About two-fifths of this band live outside the reserve and for the most part on the north side of the Beaver River. The land they occupy is not so favorable for agriculture as on the reserve; yet it is by no means bad; and as they are persistent in their request for an extension of the reserve northward across the Beaver River and toward Cold Lake, the entire band would, I think, agree to the exchange of a portion of good land in the southern or western part of the reserve for an equal area north of the river. If this were granted the location of the various families would be fairly well fixed, and two day schools, one near the Mission and the other a few miles north of the River, would serve the needs of the band, one or other being within reasonable distance of all with a very few exceptions. Provided two such schools were furnished with capable teachers devoted to their work, the children of destitute parents clothed, and a plain but wholesome meal provided for the children at noon, in addition to the usual accessories of school work, the work of education would be accomplished, and the general well-being of the children attained, under very favorable conditions and at a moderate cost.

Sir:

When I rested at Cold Lake en route from Onion Lake to the Saddle Lake School, I was waited upon by the Chief and leading men of the Chipewyan Band, No. 124, whose Reserve is in the vicinity of the lake.

They represented to me that there are some fifty children of school age in the Band, and that they urgently desire that they should have the means of receiving a good education, moral, as well as mental and manual. They stated, with intelligent appreciation of changing conditions, that the pressure of white settlement must push farther and farther into the background the Indian untrained in the means employed by the white man for securing a livelihood and ensuring advancement.

With equally intelligent appreciation of their own condition, which makes day-schools for their children educationally futile, they very emphatically made known that what they desired was a boarding, not a day school! "We go," they said, "hunting and trapping, and we have to take our children with us. We would lose the means of making a livelihood in which we are skilled were we to remain at home to send our children to a day-school, were there one. That is out of the question. The only way to really provide for the education of our children is by establishing a boarding school."

There would not be room enough to accommodate all the available children of this band at the Onion Lake School. In addition to the children on the Cold Lake Reserve there are Chipewyan children lacking the means of education at Hart Lake.

But even if there were room at the Onion Lake School,
or if its capacity were increased for the purpose of providing
for them, it would be practically impossible to prevail upon
the Chipewyans to send their children to a school in which Crees
predominate. "We do not" said their leader, "like to send our
children to school with Cree children, for they do not get along
well together". But the objection lies deeper than that. The Crees
and Chipewyans are hereditary enemies. They are of distinctly
different stocks. They differ in character, and differ consider-
ably even in external appearance. The line of cleavage is
well marked in their languages.

The Chipewyans are tractable and teachable; and it
would be sound policy to provide them with acceptable means of
education. They expressed a keen desire for a boarding school;
and my enquiries compelled the belief that they are determined
to make good use of one, if provided. They assured me they would
be grateful for the boon.

At Cold Lake and at part Lake the Indians are all
Catholics, and those who approached me distinctly asked for a
boarding school under the auspices of the Catholic Church.

An elderly man and a leader among his people,
stated that when Governor Morris made the treaty with them
he promised that provision would be made for the education of
their children; and he complained that since that time nothing
had been done for the education of the Chipewyans, whose children,
in the meantime, were to their very great disadvantage, growing up
in ignorance.

I was given to understand that these Indians had
several times asked the Department to establish a boarding
school for them.

I shall be pleased to hear that the Department will
favorably consider making early provision for establishing the
much desired school.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to draw your attention to the Cold Lake school, and to ask you what you intend to do for the Chippewyan children of this Reservation. The influenza has made quite a few orphans amongst them, and if you do not do something for them, they will live a miserable life. Belonging to no one, they will be passed from one family to another, and not well treated by any. You cannot send them to the Onion Lake school, as past experience has shown that Chippewyan children die when sent away from their reserve.

Could you not build a small boarding school on this reserve for the number of children of school age. There are not so many of them, and as they cannot be sent out, it seems the only way to help them, above all the orphans who have no claim on any body but the Department.

Additions could be made to the present school to accommodate all the children, and without too great an expense. Please, Dear Sir, remember the Chippewyan orphans, and do come to their assistance.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the request of Rev. Father Grandin to have a small boarding school on the Cold Lake Reserve for the accommodation of the Chippewayan children there I beg to say that he states that there are some children made orphans by the epidemic of influenza on the reserve and that the Indians object to sending their children to Onion Lake, as they claim that many of them die when sent away from the reserve. Father Grandin states that there are not many children there who would need to be provided for and he suggests that an addition could be made to the present building to accommodate them, without any great expense.

There is a day school in operation there, in charge of the Rev. Sister Eugenie, held in the mission building, which is the property of the Oblate Fathers.

Last year Mr. Inspector Crombie suggested that the Department might advance them $250.00 for the purpose of purchasing lumber and erecting an addition to the present building to provide extra class-room accommodation; repayment to be made by the mission from the rent which they are charging the Department for the school-room, $240.00 per annum. On the 18th of June, last, Rev. Father Dauphin was asked whether he would be willing to carry out the Inspector's suggestion. No reply has been received to that letter.

Mr. Inspector Crombie, in his last report on the Cold Lake Day School, made in November, 1917, states that the school is doing good work, but, like other reserves where the parents earn part of their living by hunting, there are times when the children are kept from school. He also
states that there is a great opportunity here for school work and, if a good attendance can be maintained, much good will result. If a few boarders could be provided for, it would not be necessary for the parents to take the children with them when absent from the reserve, and the school work would not be interrupted.

The Department has no definite information as to the number of orphans there, and I would suggest that Mr. Inspector Crombie be asked for a report on Father Grandin's application. Of course the Department should not be asked to expend money on enlarging a building which does not belong to it, but, if the Oblate Fathers would provide accommodation, a per capita grant might be allowed them for the maintenance of a few children.

Referring to your letter of the 8th ultimo, No. 115-3-1, I have the honour to report that when at Cold Lake reserve on the 12th instant, I called at the R.C. Mission for the purpose of ascertaining from the Rev. Father Balter, the position with respect to re-opening the Day School at that place.

Father Balter stated that, in his opinion, it was hopeless to try to re-open the school. He pointed out that the Indians of the Chipewyan band are almost entirely hunting Indians, and that they are away from the reserve, following their vocation, for lengthy periods and take their whole family with them, but that they would willingly leave the school children if there was any place at which they could leave them. He also said that when the Day School was first opened, it was with the understanding that the Department would shortly establish a Boarding School on the reserve; and, at first, the Indians made every effort to have their children attend; but, as the prospect of obtaining a Boarding School diminished, the Indians lost heart and made little effort to send their children to the Day School. Father Balter added that should the Department consider building a Boarding School on the reserve, he felt sure that the Sisters of Charity - who were in charge of the Mission and Day School - would come back and re-open the Day School pending the building of a Boarding School.

I may say, in this connection, that there are about 35 children of school age in the Chipewyan band. During the first year the Day School was open, 1916, the average attendance was 27 whilst during the last year the average was 12 only.

It is a matter of regret that the school is closed and that the Sisters have left. Apart from the school work, their presence on the reserve and their visits to the homes of the Indians, undoubtedly had a good effect; particularly in the case of the Chipewyan women, who are now, noticeably, more clean and tidy in their dress and homes than formerly. However, it appears that nothing can be done just at present towards the re-opening of the Day School. A new Roman Catholic Bishop, in place of the late Archbishop Legal, has been appointed, and Father Balter has not yet been able to communicate with him on the subject.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo No. 115-3-1, with reference to the proposed re-opening of the Indian Day School on the Chipewyan reserve at Cold Lake.

At the census taken recently there were 45 children of school age in the two Chipewyan bands at Cold Lake. Of these 14 are enrolled at the Onion Lake (R.C.) Boarding School, leaving a balance of 31. After deducting from this number all those who for any reason could not attend the Day School it appears to me that an average attendance of 20 is a very conservative estimate, and could reasonably be expected.

I was again at Cold Lake on October 30th, and called upon Father Balter at the Roman Catholic Mission there; he seems very keen and enthusiastic over the prospect of the re-opening of the Day School. Formerly, when the Sisters of Charity were living at the Mission the Indian Day School was held in one of the rooms there which had been enlarged for that purpose. However, since the Sisters have left the Mission building, it has again been used as quarters for the priests, who have given up the building they formerly occupied. This is the building that would now be used for school purposes. The room intended for the classroom is 21 ft. square. The building is a log one, two storied and shingled. It is a good building in every respect, and the remainder of the building would be occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Lirette, if they are appointed teacher and field matron respectively. Father Balter told me that he would expect to be paid the same rental as formerly, i.e. $20.00 per month. At the time of my visit the building was undergoing necessary repairs to the plaster, etc.; it has been unoccupied for the past twelve months.

Very little equipment would be required as there is now on hand at Cold Lake, 20 double school desks, a teacher's desk and two chairs.

I reminded Father Balter that about a year ago he had thought it hopeless to attempt a re-opening of this Day School. He is of the opinion that conditions have now changed (insofar as the sentiment of the Indians towards a Day School is concerned), I agree with him and that if the School is now re-opened it will have a good attendance. This also is my view, and I may add that the chief of the band told me that if the school is re-opened he will use his influence to have all the children attend.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

CONSTRUCTION OF A BOARDING SCHOOL:- The Superintendent of Education must have heard about this request which must be in the Files of the Department. I have received lately strong letters from Rev. Fr Balter O.M.I. of Legoff about this important matter and I wish to draw your attention to it in stating the reasons in favour of the erection of a boarding school and in making a formal request for it. The reasons set forth are the following:

a) The children on the reserve have a right to education according to the treaties;

b) The Department of Indian Affairs having studied the question before the war had reached the conclusion that a boarding school was a necessity. The construction was delayed by the war but now as before the circumstances have not changed and the same necessity (if not greater) is still existing;

c) The day school in spite of the good will of the Indians cannot give satisfactory results. It is true a certain number of children draw a little benefit from the school but the Department is aware that our Indians live in the woods most of the time, hunting, etc. They necessarily bring their children along. Even when the Indians stay on the reserve as the latter is very large it is almost cruel to ask from the children to attend school regularly during Winter. To His Grace H.J.O'Leary,

Your Grace,

At several times in the past we have petitioned the Indian Department for the construction of a boarding school and hospital on the Cold Lake Reserve.

The Department of Indian affairs having studied the question before the war, had reached the conclusion that a Boarding School and a Hospital was a necessity. The construction was delayed by the war, but now as before the circumstances have not changed and the same necessity (if not greater) is still existing.

As far as the Boarding School is concerned the children on the two Reserves have a right to education according to the treaties. The Day School in spite of the good will of the Indians cannot give satisfactory results. It is true a certain number of children draw a little benefit from the Day School, but the Department is aware that the Chipewyan Indians live in the woods most of the time, hunting etc. They necessarily bring their children along. Even when the Indians stay on the Reserve as the latter is very large it is almost cruel to ask the children to attend school regularly especially during the winter. Kindly note also that there is a small reserve situated at 15 miles from Legoff and the children can in no way attend school.

Referring to the construction of a hospital, I beg to inform Your Grace that for a few years past mortality seems to have been more marked among the Chipewyan Indians than on other Reserves. According to the Doctors themselves (Dr. Charlebois, Dr. Hill, Dr. Sabourin), in most cases this work has been handicapped for want of a hospital, the Indians as a rule not being able to give remedies according to prescriptions. I beg to forward herewith the Estimates for the Saddle Lake Agency.

There is a matter which requires a special report from me. I refer to the school requirements for the Indians of this Agency and part of the Onion Lake Agency, viz.: Keewehins Reserve. In my opinion, the question of building a school on the Saddle Lake Agency should not be considered. The school should be built at St. Paul de Metis, and should be sufficiently large to accommodate not only the children of the Saddle Lake Reserve, but of Cold Lake and Keeheewins reserves as well. I believe that a school of the same capacity as that which we have built for the Roman Catholic Church on the Blood Reserve would meet the requirements.

I understand that the church authorities are anxious to have a school built at Cold Lake as well as at Saddle Lake. This would be a mistake, as a school centrally located would take care of the requirements of Saddle Lake and a great part of the Onion Lake Agency. Of course, if this scheme is carried out, and I think it should be, the Department should insist on closing up the day schools. In my opinion, the operating of these schools is only a useless waste of money, for which we are getting no value.

I believe that the establishing of a school at St. Paul de Metis will meet with the approval of the Archbishop of Edmonton, and the Oblate Order.

DATED OCTOBER 15, 1929, ON HIS VISIT TO
THE COLD LAKE RESERVE.

COLD LAKE RESERVE.

A number of Indians waited for me at the Mission where I stopped for lunch. Included in the number was Chief Jumbo from the Big Island Lake Reserve, and their chief object in seeing me was to again agitate for a residential school on their reserve. They claim that they were promised a school before the war and each time I visit the reserve they bring up this question, and they have it so firmly fixed in their minds that it does not appear as though they will cease agitating until they get what they are asking for. Honourable Sir:

We, the undersigned Indians of the Cold Lake Reserve respectfully beg you to take into serious consideration our often reiterated demand for the establishment of a Boarding School on our own Reserve here... Your predecessors have repeatedly promised us such a school... We were once on the point of having it, but the World War forced the Indian Department to postpone the erection of that school... Since then, the Indian Reserve Inspectors, our Agents, our Ecclesiastical Superiors have been unanimous in supporting our just demand, and in promising us a Boarding School... Sad to say!! After so many years of anxious and patient expectation, we seem to be still at the same point.

We want higher education for our children, and we want it given here on our Reserve. We shall never consent to sending our children to the proposed St-Paul school, and our sending them presently to Onion Lake, is, and was always intended to be, a temporary arrangement.

We were promised a Boarding School before it was even a question of rebuilding the Onion Lake Anglican and Catholic schools; and before there was any talk of reorganising the Saddle Lake school. Are we going to wait until all the old Boarding Schools of the West are rebuilt, before we are given our own school, which was promised us since so many years??

We feel that our rights are slighted, that somebody, somewhere, is playing with us, and we resent it very deeply!

Therefore, Honourable and Kind Sir, we once more entreat you most respectfully, but also most energetically, to reconsider our request, and to give this our school question the earliest possible solution.

We consider that our school ought to be the first on the list of the boarding schools to be built in 1930.

Should you deign to grant us our just demand (you have the power to do it) we shall forever be most grateful to you, and we shall pray the Lord to bestow upon you and those dear to you His most precious Blessings.

Sir:

For your information, I am enclosing copy of a communication of today's date to Mr. Inspector Murison, regarding the closing of the Cold Lake Indian Day School. From this letter, you will observe that the school mentioned is to be closed as from June 30th, 1933, on account of the lack of interest on the part of the parents and the poor attendance.

You should see that the building is properly secured, and any classroom equipment may be distributed to other schools in your agency. Next summer, you should endeavour to have the Indian children of school age and in good health on the Cold Lake Reserve placed in residential schools.

COLD LAKE DAY SCHOOL

I visited this school on October 19th and found only two Indian children in attendance. In addition, there were three of the Farming Instructor's children and four of the teacher's children present in the classroom. The attendance at this school, I may safely say, has never been satisfactory for any length of time. This is partly due to the indifference of the Indians regarding the education of their children and partly owing to the fact that these Indians follow hunting and trapping extensively as a means of livelihood, and, consequently this vocation necessitates their being absent from the Reserve for extended periods of time, many of them taking their whole families with them to the trap lines. The Teacher, Mr. Charles Hebert, receives a salary of $1,000.00 per year and his wife $600.00 a year as Assistant Teacher. This is a large sum of money to pay in view of the average attendance at this school. The Teacher appears bright, has a First Class Permanent Certificate for the Province of Alberta, and I am satisfied that, if he could get the attendance, he is quite capable of getting results. However, under the circumstances, no teacher however well qualified could make a satisfactory showing with such an intermittent attendance as has existed at this school.
